description: They make a wonderful al pastor burrito. I wish for something green inside the filling, but the al pastor burrito manages, somehow, to be satisfying all the way to the last bite. No burrito fatigue here - it looks like Los Compadres mashes/splits the rice grains before rolling them in, creating a texture almost similar to cornmeal. Perfect burrito diameter too - small enough to lop off in two bites, yet large enough to remain a proper burrito.
author: Josh L.

description: I got the quesadilla with carne asada mild. It was OK, the beef was a little chewy. I liked how they had like a wrap which made it possible to eat while I was driving... I was being extra careful.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I ordered a burrito today and was very explicit about NO CILANTRO and when I got back to my office and took a bite.....FULL OF CILANTRO! 

I wasted $11 (incl tip) on a burrito that wound up going directly into the trash.

At the very least, I'd like a free burrito. This time, with no damn cilantro!
author: Kevin K.

description:
Don't judge a book by its cover.  On a typical day during the work week you will usually find a line at this taco truck. For the last few months I've been perusing by thinking I should probably try out the taco truck. If that many people are in line, it must be good... but wait there's more.

While the price point is very reasonable and service is efficient, I was disappointed with the final product. Hungry and with urgency, I took my hefty carne asada burrito to a bench a few blocks away and quickly unwrapped it only to discover that the end I opened was on the soggy side. Greasy, the oil ran down my hands, hmmm. I didn't have enough napkins to absorb it all, but managed to eat half of it. 

Now about the burrito itself. The burrito was missing key ingredients that were listed in the menu in front of the truck. No cilantro. No salsa. What? Anyway, the meat seemed over cooked and the flavor was okay. Interestingly, they used a shorter rice grain which reminded me of couscous.

Truth. The taco truck serves a purpose as casual Mexican joints are pretty scarce in the area. Los Compadres continues to have its long lines and customers, I'm just not a fan.
author: Nova P.

description: I went to try Los Compadres Taco Truck on 2nd Street for lunch with two coworkers and found the food to be fairly average. They both ordered burritos while I got their al pastor quesadilla. Both of them mentioned that the burritos tasted fairly plain and I felt the same way about the quesadilla. It was not bad by any means, but it was also very simple without much flair. The al pastor was cooked well and the cheese helped to balance it out. In addition to a bag of chips at the office, it made for a fairly decent lunch though I found it to be a slight bit expensive.
author: Joshua M.

description:
3.5 stars but I'll round up. Pleasantly surprised by how tasty my quesadilla from here was. The line at noon wasn't bad, maybe just 2 people ahead of us, but I did notice more people start to queue up after we were done ordering so you might want to go right at noon or just before noon to avoid waiting in a line. 

Quesadilla was only $7 + tax, really affordable compared to a lot of the other options in the area! I count myself lucky if I'm able to get lunch in the $10 range. I ordered the chicken quesadilla and it came out piping hot and with a perfectly chewy + crispy tortilla. Nicely sized portions, I was very full after eating the whole thing. 

Friendly service as well, I plan to be back!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Is it La Taqueria or any of the greats in the mission? No. Is it the best Mexican in South Beach? Yes.

Great price is probably best thing going for it. Portion and quality are standard but nothing special. I got the carnitas burrito and found the meat a bit dry. It also wasn't folded really well but overall this place gets the job done. More flavor than your local Chipotle.
author: Victor W.

description:
Standard taco truck. $3 for a taco (plus tax)  but the tacos are bigger than most taco trucks. Not the greatest tacos but they are serviceable and the employees are  very nice. 


The world needs a San Francisco Taco ranking...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top) is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.  

Rod's SF Taco Rankings:

1 El Gallo Giro Taco truck
2 Garajito
3 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
4 La Corneta
5 Chisme
6 El Norteno Taco Truck
7 Taqueria Los Mayas 
8 Garaje
9 Taqueria Vallarta
10 Little Taqueria
11 La Taqueria
12 Taqueria Castillo
13 El Farolito
14 Pancho Villa Taqueria 
15 Taqueria el Buen Sabor
16 Panuchos
17 Taqueria Gudalajara
18 La Palma Mexicatessen
19 El Tonayense
20 Tropisueno
21 La Espiga de Oro
22 Papito Hayes
23 Tacos San Buena
24 Los Compadres Taco Truck
25 Cochinita Mayan Cuisine
26 El Taco Loco
27 Gordo Taqueria
28 Nick's Crispy Tacos

Below is my top 10 for the Bay Area in case you were curious.

2 El Jaliciense
3 Taqueria Sinaloa
4 Garajito
5 Belmar La Gallinita Meat Market
6 Belly
7 La Corneta
8 Chisme
9 El Norteno Taco Truck
10 Taqueria Los Mayas
author: Rod M.

description: I found them! On 2nd between Harrison and Folsom (Dow is nearby). I guess it's posted somewhere online, but I wasn't able to find it. Super happy I did. Their burritos are amazing as ever, and they have breakfast burritos with ham or chorizo. :D
author: Josh B.

description: I came here for lunch and ordered the carne asada burrito. This burrito had a good mixture of meat, rice, and beans. Their hot sauce had a lot of heat to it and had me sweating at the end. Ask for the spicy carrots if you enjoy pickled vegetables.
author: Carter L.

description: My personal favorite lunch truck, though I haven't been able to find them recently since their spot on Spear is under construction.
author: Lauren C.

description:
The best tacos in SoMa. Conveniently located on Spear an Folsom this is a well-visited local spot. Quick service, they accept credit cards, and the prices are fire. Two tacos for $6 or three tacos for $9. They also offer burritos, quesadillas, and a variety of add-ons (guac, sour cream, chips, etc). The quality is good and the food is consistent over many visits. 

Also, the spicy salsa is genuinely hot, so order with care.
author: Irina P.

description:
Recommendation: For a dollar more you can go to Pepe's Taqueria up the street and get a bigger burrito with a better proportion of ingredients.

After visiting Pepe's Taqueria last week, a friend had suggested that there were much better burritos down the street at a food truck. We all went this week to see what all the fuss was about. He ordered a super burrito for $9 which came with pico de gallo, sour cream, cheese, and guacamole, and everyone else ordered regular burritos without the extra filling. Note that the super burrito saves $0.50 over choosing the toppings individually, so since it's not listed on the menu it's a good thing to know if you want to save some money.

Regardless, I got my burrito after a 5-10 minute wait, which came wrapped in foil and placed in a paper bag along with a napkin. It felt heavy, despite its size! Once we got back to the office to eat though, I found it to be much less appetizing than I would have liked. As other Yelp reviewers have mentioned, there is a LOT of rice and not a lot of anything else. I wouldn't go as far as saying there's 5% meat, but it certainly was in the minority on the ingredients list. I got the spicy salsa, and it had a good amount of kick and added extra flavor, which I suppose was necessary to compensate for the lack of meat. It was also smaller in girth than the Pepe's Taqueria burrito, so I wouldn't be surprised if it were less food in general. 

To wrap it up, I think it was a meh burrito. Nothing I'd crave to eat but not like eating poison. It was pretty unremarkable. I don't think I'd recommend it, when Pepe's is right up the street in the Rincon Center, which in my opinion serves better burritos faster.
author: John B.

description:
You can't beat 2 bucks for 2 tacos! 

They offer burritos and quesadillas at unbeatable prices as well - especially in this area!

The owners at this taco truck is super nice.

Great location and with great prices!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Their super burrito is alright, like I'm not disappointed in trying it but I wouldn't come back. 

I gave them 2 stars bc I asked them first what is in their super burrito. After telling me "everything that's in the regular burrito but with guacamole, sour cream and pico de gallo", yes I ordered the super burrito. First bite I took, I noticed NO guacamole or sour cream (I told them no pico). Wait... So I basically got jipped for my money and paid for a super burrito only to get a regular burrito. It sucks you can't tell whether they included everything or not until you go home and take that first bite and it's too late to go back. 

I just hope it was an honest mistake and that their intentions were not to rip me off.
author: Cindy P.

description:
The burritos are really tasty but their expediting needs improvement. I ordered a burrito with  added guac and no beans and they gave me a burrito with just chicken and rice....no salsa or the extra item I paid for. 

This is not the first time that my colleagues and I have ordered add on items like guacamole or sour cream and they've forgotten to include them. And when you they do actually include the add on's its a pretty small serving. No longer worth the two block walk from the office.
author: Lillie J.

description:
I can't speak for their other burritos, but the al pastor burrito is extremely DELICIOUS. Why do people still go to chipotle when they can come here for a burrito that is a little bit cheaper? Admittedly, it might not be as big as a chipotle burrito, but it is definitely miles better in terms of taste. Wait is a bit long during lunch time busy hours. 
$7 burrito in SF...definitely one of the cheaper options for lunch.
author: Kay C.

description:
Either they have stepped up their game since the price increase or I came on a really really great day 

Simply put, my carne asada burrito was the best one I have had to date from them, period! 

Overall Thoughts

If the price increase is being used to elevate the food then they have certainly done a fantastic job
author: Eddie W.

description:
PROS:
grilled burritos
local
plenty of meat

CONS:
bland
small
bad wrap- one side is meat and the other side beans
so little salsa, I thought there was none

So it is not a bad place but definitely not one of the best.  They need to up the flavor in the meat, add more salsa, wrap it better.  They would get a extra boost if they offered the burrito for less than $7 and a veggie version or a simple beans rice cheese and salsa version.

Staff was friendly.
author: Bucky W.

description:
I had just eaten at BBQ food truck when I happened by this place and thought, why not!  I ordered the mini taco plate with chicken and spicy red sauce and since it was only $5 (and had mini in its name) I thought it might be more like a snack. Turned out it was a reasonably sized meal and a real bargain at that price when compared to the $8 sandwich I had just eaten.

Double wrapped tortilla's were fresh, soft and  thick.  Meat was excellent and the sauce was very hot, but not stupid hot.
author: Raymond M.

description:
I went to college in Southern California. I am now a Mexican food snob. That being said, I always saw this truck parked by my office on Sacramento. There's never been an excessive line so I always walked by it. Tuesday came around and I wanted some tacos...or Mexican food in general. I grabbed my colleague and down we went...to the food truck. For Mexican food. Luckily having a food truck is the thing to do now, because I can clearly remember when the only people that ate off of those things were the people building the houses in my subdivision. I digress.

J and I went to the truck and low and behold, there were a couple of people waiting for food and only one other person waiting to order. My spidey senses started tingling. The prices were also so cheap. I couldn't believe I was in the FiDi about to order food for less than $10. Something had to be wrong.

I ordered a carne asada burrito. Being the snotty brat that I am, I had to add some Tomatillo salsa, cheese, and duh guacamole. The dude took my order, swiped my card, handed me a receipt and a number. Then came the wait.

It was so fast, I was surprised. Once again, I was curious as to how the eff a food truck just made my food so quickly. J ordered two tacos -- for $5. Weird? I thought so. 

We received our meals. They even gave me a paper plate and napkin. Cute right?

We walked back around the corner and decided to indulge outside since it's finally Summer in San Francisco. I unwrapped my burrito and took a bite. Holy shit....it was amazing! That burrito was full of juice and flavor. The carne asada made me remember all of my delicious burritos from San Diego. I couldn't stop. I had to keep eating. It was that good. I even considered going back for a second because it was that delicious. BUT I didn't. I remembered that the scale is not friend right now....but I sure AF will be going back to get another burrito from there. SOON.

Best Mexican food in the FiDi!!!!
author: Sierra R.

description: Had a terrible experience with ordering a vegetarian dish and was given steak quesadilla. Mistakes happen, but the way they responded when I returned the quesadilla was rather rude.
author: Arjun S.

description:
Short Story:
A good place for burritos for a fantastic price!

Long Story:
I've been to many taco trucks and low cost Mexican restaurants and I would have to say that this place rocks!  The wait time at this place can vary.  On a rainy day it can be a few minutes but on a nice and sunny day (especially Friday) it can be up to 30 minutes!

There's a reason why the wait can be so long because the food is so awesome for such a great price.  Regular burritos are $6 and deluxe are $8.  Soft tacos are $2 per with a minimum of 2 orders.  Chips are $1.25 each.

Verdict:
I'm going back this week!
author: Michael W.

description:
Best quesadillas in the city. Haven't tried their burritos or tacos yet, but I'm sure it's just as good. I haven't found a place in San Francisco that has sauce that is has flavourful and spicy as Los Compadres!

Highly recommend ordering the al pastor quesadilla with the spiciest sauce. You will NOT regret it. It's $6 and so. so. good. 

It's taken me 3 years to find a good "mexican" place in San Francisco... and this is it! Sadly, it's only open at Spear and Folsom from 11:30 - early afternoon :( Not sure what the rest of its schedule is.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Finally, a great taco place in the financial district. How long have you been there? Why have you been hiding from me? Unfortunately for you, I'm announcing you to the world (possibly unfortunate for me too if the line starts to get long). Thankful to my coworker who shared the secret spot, I was able to enjoy great tacos for $2 each. Nothing fancy, just straight up basic tacos that hits the spot.

This place accepts credit card so don't worry about not having enough cash!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I will be detailed because I love this taco truck! 

Brief notes:
- I consider myself a taco expert 
- please trust my taco taste buds
- I usually go to Oakland taco trucks
- I have high expectations for tacos

Price: 
2 bucks a taco
6 bucks for a burrito
8 for super burrito

Time:
Long lines during lunch, I was in line behind maybe 8 people and after I ordered, only took me around 8 minutes to get my food

Service:
What service. It's a taco truck. 

THE TACO:
I ordered 3 tacos for 6 bucks. YES they do take card and not just cash. Usually taco trucks only take cash which is why this is important to point out yadadamean? 
It was absolutely amazing. Very flavorful and leaves you wanting much more. Al pastor, or spicy pork tacos is my suggestion. 

Pros: 
-they take card, still surprised 
-bomb tacos, top 5 truck I've been to ever
-located a block from the water/dock so there's a good spot to eat after you get food

Cons:
-tacos at other taco trucks are only 1.50 max
-lines can be long during lunch

Overall conclusion:
Long lines is a good thing to me, it means the food is worth waiting for. Although this trucks prices are a tad bit more, it's only 50 cents per taco more and it is after all in the financial district where most food places ask for 10+ for sure. Quality of the food is top notch. Once again, I live for tacos so just trust me.
author: Ben T.

description:
I've had the burritos, tacos and quesadillas and all were good. I usually get the carnitas or al pastor which are both very good.

Also, they are not very pricey. The line can be long but it moves quickly.
author: Ed G.

description:
Overall pretty good stuff offered there. Good flavors, seems like quality ingredients are used. Friendly staff. Couple ways they could improve. Size- it's not a huge or even a large burrito. Very medium, really could use a bit more heft. Dry- I like way they package them more of a tubular versus chunky as it makes it easier to eat especially if you are driving. I also order it on the drier side but these need just a bit more something, sour cream, more cheese and salsa. Chips and salsa - always wish for just a few with the meal and a side of salsa. If you want extras then charge. 

I do recommend this place just with a few tweaks could be great.
author: Chris N.

description:
I usually go to this place during lunch. I would have to say that it is the best taco/mexican food place within the vicinity. The line gets pretty long real fast during lunch time, so if you get there around 12:30 expect a long line. Overall the food is very good, meat is flavorful and comes with good sauce. Only thing is the tacos are kind of small. Even 3 does not fill me up sometimes and it cost almost $8. I would recommend getting the burrito if you are really hungry.

Overall I would rate this place as 4 star. Food is tasty but the long lines make it less appealing.
author: Tony H.

description: While it's not my favorite Taco truck in SF, it definitely does the job of providing a tasty non-Tex-Mex burrito or taco if you are nearby in FiDi. The price is pretty reasonable for what you are getting... if you add extra toppings such as sour cream, cheese and guacamole, and also add chips/salsa to your order, the total cost comes out to be similar to what you would pay for a burrito elsewhere. The chips are homemade and are definitely tasty. The staff is also very friendly, which is a plus. Again, not my favorite taco truck, but definitely, if you are craving a burrito or taco in FiDi, stop by here.
author: Kunal N.

description:
I found Los Compadres while searching Yelp for some Mexican restaurants around a new office I had started working at. It is located down the street on Spear between Howard and Folsom streets.

FREQUENCY: This was my first time ordering at this establishment.

FOOD: Los Compadres tacos are $3. Being a huge Mexican food fan I indulged and got 3. I got two spicy pork and one chicken. I live in the Mission District so I've become accustomed to delicious traditional Mexican food places. Los Compadres is definitely a traditional taco truck. I got served my three tacos on a plate with tin foil covering them. When I sat down to eat my taco-y awesomeness that plate looked like a battle had been fought on it. I don't know about everyone else but I like a messy taco when ordering from a place like this. To me that means its really good. That aside, the tacos were all delicious when it came to meat and toppings. I'm a big fan of spicy so I think I enjoyed the spicy pork more than the chicken but both were great. I'd really like to try their other taco types. Apparently the taco's used to be cheaper which has caused some lower reviews but since I never experienced anything other than the $3 tacos I was very satisfied with what I got for what I paid.

DRINK: I didn't order any drinks while at Los Compadres so I can't speak much to what they offer. I'm assuming they have the standard food truck offerings of fountain drinks and water.

ATMOSPHERE: Since this is an outdoor stand I can't say there is much an atmosphere for Los Compadres. It's located on the sidewalk and you just wait in line to order, get your taco's, and most likely eat somewhere else.

STAFF: The staff was friendly when taking my order. Since taco stands serve in a fast food like style you don't really spend much time talking with the staff.

PAYMENT: Credit cards or cash were acceptable.

This taco stand had good food and I plan to work this into my regular lunch stops. I'll update this review once I've tried all of the taco's offered.
author: Christopher D.

description: They've increased their prices a bit, so burritos are now $7. It's still decently priced, but considering it's gone from $6 to $6.50 and now to $7 in the span of one year, I'm wondering if they are going to keep raising the prices.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Rice burritos where the price keeps going up (I believe from $5.50 to $7.50 in less that 2 years). Visited for the 1st time in nearly a year out of desperation and learned that they also change tax now....so you are looking at a rice burrito for just about 9 bucks that not long ago was $5.50. Pepe's at Rincon Center has much better burritos with a fair portion of meat for the same price now. Go to Pepe's, its just 1 block away from Los Compadres. My guess is these Los Compadres guys are on their last legs....
author: Jim R.

description: I asked for my receipt after I received my food from the pickup window and the guy had a little tantrum. He slammed his fist on the counter and mumbled something under his breath. If it's too much to ask for a recipt then many you should switch to cash only. I'll stick to PePe's in the Rincon center. I almost didn't eat my tacos because the service left a bad taste in my mouth. Even though the tacos were good I won't be back.
author: Kaylan W.

description:
Best burrito in FiDi/SOMA, no doubt.  The options in this part of town aren't much, but Los Compadres easily wins the competition by a significant margin.

I've been a regular here during the lunch hour for 4+ months and I'll be sad to leave it behind when I move offices to another part of the Bay Area.  Like clockwork, every day I show up for my al pastor burrito and like clockwork, every day they make a delicious and very filling lunch at a highly affordable price, especially for the neighborhood.  Their chicken burritos are pretty good and their carne asada burritos are superb, but the al pastor burrito is heavenly delicious.  For the FiDi/SOMA area, this place is a steal (I guess it's because they don't have to pay insane commercial rent).

The folks that work the truck are really friendly and know all the loyal customers' faces.  The only real problem is that sometimes they run out of ingredients due to popularity, and at times they are overwhelmed by the long lines during lunchtime and the wait can be 15-20 minutes.  These are pretty minor complaints in my book.
author: David B.

description:
WARNING: this place hates vegetarians!

I went there for a quick lunch the other day and asked for two vegetarian taco's. "We don't have vegetarian taco's," I was told. "That's okay, just make it with beans and cheese and not meat." "We've been open for ten years and we've never done vegetarian."  Which is odd because old menus show vegetarian burritos. "I'll pay full price, just please don't put any meat in the tortillas." "I can't do that. The computer isn't set up that way." "Put in any meat you want in the computer." Just don't put meat in the taco." "Can't." "Wow. You know you're losing business." "No I'm not." 
Really!!!

I suggest walking two blocks to Market and 2nd to Uno Dos. Food way better and service great!
author: SCOTT L.

description:
If you're wondering if this truck is good, visit at 12:30 on any day. Go on, I'll wait here for you  . . .

Ridiculously long line, right? That's because this is the best burrito in the FiDi; trust me, I've tried them all and Compadres is the best. This place has been open since well before the food truck craze, back when food trucks were known as roach coaches. Pioneers indeed.

I can't put my finger on what it is exactly, but I think the fact they grill the burrito after it's constructed is key. The texture is just right; who likes a gummy tortilla? And that quick grill gets stuff inside slightly runny and all mixed together. The amount of spice is great (you can ask for mild or spicy), the meat is tasty without being overly salty, and the ratios are just right (meat to other stuff). 

I used to work closer; a mere three blocks away and I'd go about twice a month, but I now work north of Market, which is a shame because I hardly ever visit Compadres anymore. But on those rare occasions I don't eat at my desk, I walk the 15 minutes for a Compadres burrito. Yes, I'm willing to walk 15 minutes AND stand in a long line for this place. That means it's really good or I'm really stupid. Probably both.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Los Compadres, tu eres mi amigo
You're pretty solid mexican, a lot more than just so-so
You're Carne asada is the bomb, and I like the pastor too
You run a tight ship, a pretty efficient burrito making crew.

Best Mexican taco truck this side of SOMA.  I really like their Carne Asada and Pastor burritos.  Their regular burritos are like $6.50, which is ridiculous in the city, but that's their charm.  Cheap tasty burritos, it's a winner!
author: Dennis K.

description:
OMG YAAAAASSSSSSSSS!!!!  I was fiending for a burrito yesterday (hey, cheat meal: go hard or go home) so I went here yesterday for lunch and ordered a carne asada burrito.  This was DIVINE!  The best part is the burrito is so skinny (maybe bc I skipped the beans?), that I took it and sat on a bench on the embarcadero right by one of those windows opposite of Crunch where the people are working out on the treadmill and trying to not make awkward eye contact with me. 

T'was quite the fun experience bc I sat there like a bad (more like, evil) bish slowly devouring this beautiful burrito while these folks are in there working out at noon on a Friday.  I will be back!
author: Mia F.

description: Split burritos with a friend so was able to try their beef and pork. Both were tasty and nicely prices. I got the salsa on the side but both the mild and the hot were fresh and the hot was not very hot. All in all a great burrito at a solid price :)
author: Steven W.

description:
Good Mexican food and business men in dress shirts and slacks. Good combo :)
*note: Guys in business clothes may be seen here on the weekdays during lunchtime, but no they don't come with your order!    

This taco truck is tucked away a block or 2 away from the Embarcadaro near Cupid's Span & the Muni stop. Great location for grabbing some tacos or burritos and enjoying the view of the Bay bridge on a nice day. 

I got the 3 carne asada tacos for $5 & chips w/ salsa for $1.50. The tacos were great and chips were crispy and I loved the mild green sauce. You get your order within 5 minutes.. yay!
author: Emily C.

description:
Fresh & consistently delicious taco truck on the corner of Folsom & Spear. Perfect for a filling meal when you don't want to spend $15 for lunch in the Financial District. 

The salsas are some of my favorite I have ever tasted- as a Mexican, I am rightfully picky about my salsas. The line can get to about a 30 minute wait if you go during peak lunch time- but definitely worth it.
author: Nika C.

description: It Ian amazing tack truck! The taco was so tasty and  fresh. Thus taco truck tace card ! Very good price!
author: Komar T.

description:
The craftsmanship and packaging of the burritos is amazing. I've never had a burrito so well put together! That being said, I had myself a carnitas burrito sans the beans (not the biggest fan of beans), and there is definitely a reason why the burritos are packaged so beautifully.

If you're looking for a place that will give you an overwhelming amount of salsa, rice, meat, etc, this is def not your place. I feel like it's portion controlled and I appreciate that! I don't like biting into a burrito and having all the contents fall onto the table for me to stare at with dismay. Hence, the limited amount of contents in the burrito is what makes it so compact and in my opinion easy to eat and more enjoyable. 

The ratio of meat to tortilla was a little off. I felt there was more tortilla than actual carnitas so I was a little disappointed there. Also, although carnitas is fried pork, I wasn't keen on all the oil left at the bottom of my burrito from the carnitas. - 1 star for the leftover cooking oil in my burrito. The meat wasn't cut into eatable pieces either. I had a huge piece of skin in mine which was a little unique to me for a burrito. -1 star for the meat's presentation.

Love their speed from order to getting your food though! There was a line but they're quite efficient with their order to food service is great! Didn't have to wait longer than 5 -  7 minutes. I would come here if I was craving a portion controlled burrito. And you really can't beat the price $6.50 for a decent burrito!
author: Jo L.

description:
Mighty fine burrito for a taco truck. Great service, well organized, friendly and fast. I'll be back. I came here on a busy Friday lunch hour rush and had my lunch very fast. These people are pros with great flavor, that's why there is always a line. 

Go here, you'll like it/
author: Justin S.

description: My co-workers and I stopped by here for tacos--though most of us got burritos. We waited for like 15 minutes because these guys took too long to round up. But the food is pretty decent for the price. I got a Carne Asada burrito with guac and sour cream for only $7.75.  My colleagues who had been here before had good things to say about the Spicy Pork but I elected against that this go-round.  Overall, a decent burrito--will be back.
author: Juan T. K.

description: Good tacos, that is all.
author: Christopher Steven O.

description:
Whoa. Somehow I came to this truck at 12 noon and there were only 2 people in line. Definitely had to take advantage. 

Carnitas here are delicious! Very juicy and flavorful. The burrito is good but I should have coughed up the $0.75 for the guacamole... It was definitely missing something, but it was not bad! I like that it's not a huge brick of a burrito too. Good portion for lunch and didn't feel disgustingly full afterwards. And for $6.50, it's a great deal. I ordered and got my food in under 5 minutes. 

Next time I may try the carne asada. Give it a go!
author: Kelly E.

description: I've gotten burritos from this truck hundreds of time, and I'm still hungry for more! Burritos are big and delicious (BBQ pork is a favorite). Tacos are great too!
author: Tyler S.

description: Pretty good al pastor and the service is pretty quick. Pretty busy at lunch and they wont open until 11:30am even if they have nothing to do other than sit there and talk.
author: Derek F.

description:
I'm going for five - I can't see giving these guys any less.

Perfectly located 1 block from my work, they are always super friendly, super fast, super inexpensive and omg *a-maz-ing*! I've never had Mexican food that feels healthy...until now.

I got into a habit of ordering the 3 chicken soft tacos: exquisitely spiced meat, seasoning and radishes on light tortillas for just $5. Never felt full after the fact, as this proves to be JUST the right amount of protein and carbs to keep you going through the day guilt-free. Then yesterday, I finally broke loose and went for the burrito. It, too, was the right amount and "light" in that the meat, the rice, the beans - all food that normally falls like a rock in your stomach - went down like oil. Smooth, delicious and leaving me feeling light as ever even AFTER the fact. Even the tortilla felt light! Just a buck more than the tortillas at $6. For "reals" [insert Mexican accent here].

I don't know what the secret is to their chicken, but I'm fine to live in sublime ignorance.
author: Diane B.

description: I need to remind myself these are not real mission burritos. It's the only burrito spot in the area and I give into my cravings. But each time I pay 50 cents for sour cream on top of the $7 charge, my heart breaks every time. What a waste. What a joke. Are you really Mexican? Are you really my compadre?
author: Sofiya B.

description: Excellent and legitimately spicy burritos and other assortment of mexican food. I like the chicken and beef burrito. Line gets pretty long during lunch rush, but be careful about how early you get in line as I've gotten old/dried out meat in my meal before (probably from the night/day before that they're trying to use up). Also, it might be a good idea to open up the exquisitely wrapped items as you might be missing some add-ons that you paid extra for.
author: J S.

description: My favorite mexican place in the area.   Burritos are pretty solid, but i don't like that they charge extra for chips.  Chips should be free!
author: Michael E.

description:
Venga vale, vale venga!

This place is delicioso!  The al pastor is SO, SO good.  I've been here about 4 times now, and every time I am rewarded with delicious goodness.  Their Super Taco is hands down my favorite, but their Burrito and Super Burritos are just as divine.

My colleagues love the quesadilla - it weighs about 5 lbs and looks like it is just asking to be devoured.

Props to these guys also, as everything always tastes super fresh and their guacamole is super good - consistently excellent.  They also don't go crazy on the oil or fat - the meat is always fresh and satisfying - none of that 'wow this is super good, but I will definitely regret it later' type of meat.

Bottom line: If you crave Mexican para almuerzo - GO already!
author: Lauren B.

description: Super yummy. Al pastor and carnitas burritos are my favorite. Gets crowded but line moves fast. One of my favorites.
author: James T.

description:
I went here because I wanted the quintessential San Francisco burrito truck experience. This absolutely did not disappoint.

The burrito could feed a small army. It's huge and DELICIOUS. I ordered mine with a side of guac. All sides are relatively cheap for a small container.

(As an added perk, I was glad to see that they had about two tables and a few chairs.)
author: N. M.

description: High quality food from another SF food truck. $6 carnitas quesadilla! Extra .75 for guacamole, you can't go wrong. Messy & tasty. Looking forward to trying the other items. Long line, but they move it fast. Wish they gave more napkins & a fork or spoon when you order guacamole.
author: B K.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and usually it's packed with the lunch crowd.. but today I caught a nice break between rushes. I order a spicy quesadilla and I should have known to get a drink cause they don't play around on the spice. I had a job interview up the block so I only had like one bite before I had to go but that could have potentially sent me to the emergency room! 

I went into a coughing spell( pretty embarassing) so my next review will go into what happened next.

Great food and Atmosphere..just remember to be cautious about "spicy" anything!
author: Lauren S.

description: Love this truck!  I get the chicken burrito with everything, I've never experienced dry chicken, it's always been excellent!  The flavors are great, the salsas are nice.  I have no complaints about this truck  -- highly recommend.
author: Naps V.

description:
On my expedition to try the various food stands of SF, I decided to try Los Compadres. It was on my way and the price range fit my newly graduated poor student/person food budget. Plus, it was on the way to my future destination. 

I first heard about this taco truck 2 years ago while I was interning and my coworkers recommended that if I were to go anywhere for tacos, go to the place on Folsom and Spear.

Sadly, despite the wonderful line/wait of 2-3 people in front of me, those high expectations fell short after I got my tacos and reached for that dream of mouthwatering, yummy deliciousness. 

Don't get me wrong, the taco's not bad. It's ok. But, I was expecting to taste the motherhood of all tacos and it's probably because I bought the taco at 1:30PM instead of at 11AM, when the meat was fresh, that my taco didn't taste as sinfully orgasmic as I hoped it would. The carnitas had decent flavor, but was slightly dry, and the taco just didn't have multiple or even one flavor explosion in my mouth. 

Maybe, next time?
author: Rebecca H.

description:
This place has some good tacos.  The 3 soft tacos for $6 is a good price.  They come topped with cilantro, onions and radish.  The carne asada and lengua meats were both very tender.  Also, get a jarrito soda too, only $1 more.

I arrived at 11:35am on a Monday and there was no line, but maybe because it was chilly too.
author: Kevin W.

description:
As an Southwestern exile in a City that really doesn't seem to grasp Mexicn food, I love this truck.  Cheap, plentiful, usally served on a corn tortilla.  I still don't understand, and probably never will, this City's insitence on stuffing rice into burritos, but I can live with it.  The Supertaco is almost too much food for six dollars.

This good stuff.  Mexican street food, staright from the soul.
author: Rob F.

description: I might have higher Mexican food expectations than most people since I recently moved from Texas. The burritos here are ok. Nothing amazing, but they are good enough whenever I have a burrito craving. I've gotten the carne asada and the carnitas burritos and both are good, but not very memorable. If you're nearby and craving burritos, it's a good spot to get food, but you won't be blown away.
author: Erica C.

description:
The bomb!  I am soooo burnt out on Chipotle, this truck is pumping out some great grub.  I will be making it a weekly stop.

Great job guys!
author: Clark A.

description: One of the better taco trucks.  City health rating is very high as well.  Get there early, the line backs up quickly, but they are pretty quick to move it along.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Great tacos served in a truck?  Believe it!  What a perfect place for a take out lunch.  While you can easily have lunch here for under $8, I wouldn't call their $1.50 tacos cheap since each taco is so small.  I needed to eat 2 tacos and a cheese quesedia to become completely full.

By the way, the beef they use in their tacos is SO good.  Not one of those completely ground down meat like Taco Bell, but half-way ground beef with tasty seasoning and nice hot sauce.  The hot peper it comes with is also very good.  Thumbs up!
author: トモ T.

description: The carne asada burrito is dry and underwhelming. The flavors and spices used are good but the meat and beans make up the majority of the burrito and lack moisture. Haven't tried their other items. Burrito came very neatly and tightly wrapped in tin foil in a paper bag. There were about 10 other people in line when I got there around 12:15pm. Was about a 10 min wait for an order of one burrito and one quesadilla.
author: Ning T.

description: Fast, delicious, and they accept credit card. What more could you want from a taco truck?
author: Victoria W.

description:
got the super sized taco and they weren't kidding about the super size part.  I got the beef tongue taco and it was delicious.  I did ask for the spicy one but i thought the spice was just perfect. 

get their super sized taco!!!!!
author: JY L.

description: How do they make the carne asada so delicious?? I've been coming here for lunch for several months now and this place is quick (even if there's a line), well priced (for fidi) and sevice is friendly. Thanks taco truck!
author: katrina w.

description:
Maybe I shouldn't write this review; that way, there won't be a longer lunch line when I come back. :)

Finally! A food place that isn't overpriced/tasteless/borderline inedible in the Financial District of San Francisco! I am thrilled to have discovered this place, with the help of some coworkers. Like a bright gleaming beacon of hope, it is only a few blocks from where I work! 

I am a huge, huge fan of taco trucks. They taste better than any Mexican restaurant I've been in. For some reason, SF's food trucks like to jack up their prices to unreasonable amounts -- $10 for a lunch?!(To account for the extremely difficult task of of handling a social media page, mayhaps?) No thanks. I am incredibly thankful that this little treasure, an authentic Mexican food truck, does not exhibit the same horrible characteristics.

I tried 3 carne asada tacos for $5, and was not disappointed. They certainly filled me up for lunch! I will be back to try the burrito, super taco, super burrito: all of the above.
author: Mina K.

description:
I'm loving the tacos at Los Compadres!  3 tacos for $5...and they're filling too.  The pollo asado, carnitas, & al pastor are all excellent.  

They also have a massive super taco for $6.  Silly me thought that one taco would surely not be enough for my huge lunchtime appetite.  Wrong!  I could barely finish it.  It ended up being more like a tostada salad with meat, beans, rice, cheese, sour cream, pico de gallo, lettuce, guac, & salsa, with a side of radish, pickled jalapenos & carrots.  I had to eat 2/3 of the filling before I could pick the darned thing up.  They also serve quesadillas & burritos, so I'll try those next.  

You can eat your meal at one of their cute little tables next to the truck or walk a block over to the sunny Embarcadero waterfront & enjoy the view.

My new cheap meal deal in SOMA!
author: Erin S.

description:
Yummy yum yum...I'm so glad to have a taco truck like this only a couple of blocks away from my office!

It can get really busy during the height of the lunch hour, but I usually try to go on the early side when the wait isn't so bad.  The carne asada super taco (my usual) comes with a generous helping of meat and it's loaded down with rice, beans, lettuce, salsa, cheese, onion, guac and sour cream.  This thing is huge...and heavy!  It's on a soft taco and they provide you with a fork, but I end up picking up the taco part with my hands once I've eaten some of the fixings off the top.  (I eat this at my desk so nobody has to witness me tackling this monster!)  Combine the taco with a bag of their thick, crispy chips and a side of salsa (which is included with the order) and you have some goooood tasty eatin'...all for $7.50!  I always order mine spicy (vs. mild) because I love spicy food, but you should know that it really IS spicy.  

For anyone who might be wary about eating from a taco truck (like I originally was), they have a perfect 100 rating from the health department.  That definitely set my mind at ease!

OK, I'm going back to eating now....
author: Kimberly B.

description: I love fine dining as much as any girl, but I equally love food trucks!  This isn't one of those "fancy" food trucks (complete with Twitter page) by any means... but I love their street tacos, and at 3 for $5, the price is right.  For your taco order, You get your choice of meats and salsa.  My favorite meats: carne asada, carnitas, al pastor.  I typically like my sauces mixed (red + green salsa on each taco).  There's no place to sit nearby, but you can eat outside at South Park (about 2 blocks away) or bring them back with you to enjoy!
author: Sarah T.

description: Go-to spot for burritos. Their quesadillas are very good too. I like the carnitas -- tender and a little bit crispy in some places. Their salsas have great flavors.
author: Leah B.

description:
Great source of Mexican food and joy. The "super" items in the menu are good for two portions.

The Super Quesadilla is great and the 3 tacos deal is something to try.
author: Ibai G.

description: I've been frequenting this taco truck for a few years and it was always great! Sometimes there could be a crazy long line but the food was always worth it. I hadn't been in a few months and went a couple of weeks ago. The regular crew was gone, and I was informed that I could no longer order a super taco which was always my favorite! I was sad, but ordered some chicken tacos instead. When I ate my tacos I was very disappointed because the meat was dry & rubbery. I don't know what happened but it's just not the same and I doubt that I will be back. So very sad :(
author: Kimberly R.

description: $8 super carne asada burrito minus the beans and cheese. Side of chips and tomatillo for a buck something more. What a satisfying meal and thankfully something different. I love my salads and soups but this chubby girl needs her guilty pleasures and I've found another stop to add to my list. I'm definitely going for the tacos next!!!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
This place just plain sucks. It's a freakin truck yet they charge you *more* than a brick and mortar taco place and the portions are minuscule. But hey, you'll be handed your tacos wrapped in a ghetto paper plate by a hipster with tats & Elvis Costello glasses.

Do yourself a service, walk a few blocks east to mexico au park, you will be able to sit, eat more quantities of better stuff and pay less.
author: Ho N.

description:
First off, note that this review is relative to the location; move this to the Mission, it'd only get two stars.  But, there's much fewer options around here.

Their burritos are one-meal sized, not two.  Their chips are outstanding (for a dollar extra).  They have two tables out front to sit at, and a long line at lunch, but one that usually doesn't take more than five minutes or so to get through.  

This review is part of a series on lunch places near my office.
author: Zachary R.

description:
For what it is and where it is, it's 5 stars. I like getting 3 tasty authentic tacos for $5. That's a real value for the neighborhood. Very similar to the style tacos at Mijita nearby at the Ferry Building, which are also quite tasty, but those are $4.25 each. 

There's often a line, but if you go a little early before noon, it's a much shorter wait. Even when there's a long line, it moves relatively fast. 5-10 minute wait tops.
author: Ryan K.

description: Slowest taco truck in existence and they never have anything to drink. Overpriced. Not that good.
author: Spyro K.

description: Not a very good burrito.  Ordered the Carne Asada burrito, I must've been unlucky or something, but it's probably the worst burrito I've ever had.  The beef was so gristly that it was actually crunchy... and when it wasn't grisly I was just chewing on chunks of stringy fat.  Barely got any bites of actual meat.  Even if I had gotten unlucky with a bad batch of meat, the rice also tasted like that "instant spanish rice" you find at the dollar store and there was almost no salsa.  Don't understand why this place has such good reviews.  At least I know not to come back.
author: Casey S.

description:
Lone taco truck in the outer reaches of the FiDi, well hidden in a parking lot.  The tacos use tiny soft corn tortillas that are good, but not freshly griddled.  A nice mix of cilantro, onions, red salsa and green salsa top each taco.  Probably better Mexican food than most restaurants in the hood, though some of the meats tend to be bland.

Quesadilla: I really wasn't enthusiastic about getting this at first, but I figured I wanted a little extra food in case I was still hungry after the tacos.  This was by the far the best menu item!  It wasn't like those half moon quesadillas I'm quite familiar with, but more of a crispy rectangle with all the sides closed off.  Inside was gooey queso blanco with fresh cilantro leaves and a tomato-based hot sauce.  I still can't get over how perfectly crispy it was!!!

Carne Asada Taco: Little morsels of steak with a bit of grill charring.  All well done, no rare or medium rare sections like found in hoity-toity carne asada.  Good for a humble taco truck.

Al Pastor Taco: My favorite of the tacos.  Extremely crispy and spicy small cubes of pork.  Even dripping a bit of flavoring (i.e. grease) to add extra taste.

Carnitas Taco: Got the texture right: some soft pulled pork and some crispy.  The flavor just wasn't there, seemed a bit bland.  Decent, but so many better carnitas around town.

Chicken Taco: Probably the most boring.  Tasted like boiled chicken without any spices.  I prefer chicken tacos that have a chicken which has been stewing for hours.
author: Adam B.

description: This place sucks... It's right across from my building and they nickle and dime you for every little thing.  The burritos are small as hell.  Don't waste your time when you can go to other places that are much better in the city
author: David L.

description: Quick fix for Mexican food.  Great tacos.  Be prepared for a wait during the lunch hour
author: C G.

description: This is the finest Mexican fare around.  Don't get me wrong, I'm all about the greasy, dive taquerias, but this is well-made food for sure.  On first site, I knew it was good from the number of people waiting patiently for their lunch orders.  I will definitely stop by again my next time in the Bay Area!
author: Jeff M.

description: Overall, not bad - just whoever the guy is that replaced the girl, (he always wears his sunglasses), has the "too cool for school" attitude.  No, please don't look up from your phone to let me know that the truck isn't open till 11:30, (I thought it was 11).  "yeah" consistitutes the least amount of effort, but when you're the face of a business, kick it up a notch "bro"
author: Kelly S.

description: Super solid taco truck. Legit and lives up to the hype. Burrito was downright amazing. Misses one star, because it is, after all, a food truck.
author: Brian C.

description:
The burritos here are bomb diggity!!

This place is quite a bit of a walk from my office, but the food is worth every step rain or shine! Last time my co-worker and I came here, we walked in the pouring rain to get our burrito fix. 

The burritos here are HUGE. Between 3 people we split 2 super burritos and 2 chips and salsa, and we were STUFFED. Now you can imagine how big the burritos are. They are also packed tight! They are so dense and heavy that the paper bag almost ripped when we were carrying our feast back to the office in the rain. Thanks to my co-worker's cat like reflexes, our lunch was saved!! Besides the size of the burrito, I think it is constructed pretty well. Every ingredient that is in there is of the right amount. Not too much or not too little. I also like how the burrito itself doesn't seem to greasy. Some of the burritos I've eaten around the city have pools of oil in them, and that REALLY bothers me. 

Minus one star for charging us for extra salsa. I'm glad that the chips comes with a rather large salsa, but when you ask for more they will charge you. There are 2 kinds and personally, I like the green one better because the red one has this smokey taste which I don't really like too much. But, why do they charge us for more salsa? The other taco trucks don't...
author: Ayaka S.

description: Had them for a few times, asked what was in the super/deluxe burrito and I ordered 3 times 2 deluxe 1 normal and they were the same. My 2 deluxe burritos didn't have the guac or anything special compare to the regular. Save your 2 dollars and just get regular... unless they forgot to put those extras in twice
author: Harold W.

description:
Flatly, the best lunch place in the neighborhood. The burritos are soooo good. 

Very friendly. Fast service.
author: Kevin K.

description: They raised prices this week. Gave you less and didn't have carnitas, black beans,  al pastor or refrained beans.  I don't like paying more for less. No more:(
author: Eduardo L.

description: I eat here regularly because it is so close to my office and have a great experience every time. The line gets ridiculously long but it's worth the wait. Plus if you come back 30 mins later then the line is usually gone. I love the chicken burrito (w/ pico, guac, cheese and sour cream) and the quesadillas are amazing. The quesadillas are not a typical quesadilla because you eat it like a compact burrito. The food is always fresh, always hot and always good time after time - what more could you ask for in a food truck?
author: Amy B.

description:
I go to this truck for lunch every so often. It helps if you get there in the 11:45 timeframe or earlier, as the line can get pretty long.

The phrase "El Tonayense" is visible along the lower edge of the truck, but the dude handling the money assured one of my coworkers that they are not affiliated with that chain of trucks. Hmm.

Good food, good value. For $6, you can get a burrito that's not overstuffed with rice, with meat that's marinated very nicely. Throw in $2 more, and they'll add in the obligatory artery-cloggers (sour cream, etc.). The tacos are very tasty as well. Vegetarian options available. And of course, they'll put on the red sauce as liberally as you want.

This is how a roach coach (note: that is NOT a derogatory term) should do food: Good, cheap, fast, and easy.

Those are desirable adjectives when describing an eatery.

Not all of them are so great if descriptive of you while on dates. But that's another story...

But um, anyway, yeah: 4.0 stars.
author: Tim B.

description:
Bankrupt, divorced from his Doberman Pinscher wife (..she would later claim that size did matter) and no longer with a corporate sponsor, the little chihuahua staggered on the street with its tiny, bony legs barely able to move. In a state of doggie dementia (much like a post-Ellen, pre-hetero Anne Heche wandering Fresno), he repeats his rainman-like mantra over and over again...

"Yo quiero Taco Bell...Yo quiero Taco Bell...Yo quiero Taco Bell..."

Luckily, he came upon the Los Compadres Taco Truck on Spear and Folsom. But it's not Taco Bell - "Donde estan los Gorditas??" - and the line is so long. He pants with hunger, and as the clock strikes noon, he has to wait a full half-hour before getting his fairly hefty $5.00 Carnitas Burrito.

It's good - not great - but filling with the appropriately overstuffed combination of black beans, rice and grilled pulled pork (though it tasted like it was sitting on the grill a little too long). It hit the spot on an unbearably hot day. Oh wait, my muchacho, I forgot about you...have a bite...how does it taste?

"Here, lizard, lizard, lizard..."

Everyone's a critic. 

FOOD - 3 stars...a solid street burrito, not quite up to the hype
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...uh, it's a truck, dummy....though there are tables and chairs but mostly for people waiting for their orders
SERVICE - 3 stars...not the fastest guns in the West
TOTAL - 3 stars...hankering for a burrito and not in a hurry?...try it
author: Ed U.

description:
Went at 1PM on a Monday.

They mixed up my order with the person before mine, but I got the correct burrito.  The wait was about five minutes.  I ordered a regular burrito with Carne Asada and the meat is a bit dry-either overcooked or old or both.  I asked for some extra salsa verde and the guy told me it was made with salsa verde (which it wasn't) and an extra would cost me $.50.

If it weren't for the beautiful day outside, I may have given this truck one star.

Every place has their bad days.  I love Mexican food and I will try this truck again earlier in the day and hope for the four star food I've been promised.
author: Curtis C.

description: The food can be pretty decent, but is woefully inconsistent and a ripoff. About half the time I get guac even though I've paid for it - no excuse for that. Or it will be all jammed into the last bite, so I don't know if i've been ripped off until the end. They also don't do refried beans - what's up with that?
author: Dan P.

description:
Perhaps I have been spoiled by the taco trucks in LA, but Los Compadres simply did not cut it for me.  I've been in SF for 3 months now and the two things I miss most about LA are taco trucks & good Korean BBQ.  As I was chasing my male coworkers up the 2nd street hill (between Howard & Folsom) yesterday on our way back from lunch, I saw a sign pointing to a roach coach.  I was super excited and if I hadn't already had lunch, I would have gone immediately.  I thought about it all afternoon and this morning and I just had to try it today for lunch.

Here are the issues I have with the taco truck:
1) $4.50 for 3 tacos??? Tacos in LA are $1 or $1.25 and I can buy as many or as few as I want.  Why must I buy 3 and why are they $1.50 each?

2) Long wait.  I ordered prior to noon and it still took 5-10 minutes to get my food.  In LA, it's instantaneous because there are more than 2 people working on the truck.

3) Most importantly - Cold meat.  I got 2 carnitas & 1 al pastor tacos and the meat was not warm by the time I got back to my desk (5 min. walk from the truck).  

4) Lemon - I'm sorry, but when did taco joints start giving out lemon instead of lime?  I know, their juice is almost the same, but it's just a sign of lack of authenticity.

Maybe if this was my first time at a taco truck, I may have been amused.  Perhaps my expectations are unrealistically high for SF.  All I can say is I can't wait to get back to LA in a month and eat as many taco truck tacos as I want!
author: Yi Z.

description: this truck is across the street from my office, so i can see how long the line is at all times! BEST 3 tacos plate for $5.00. i always get the lingua, so tender and moist. the health review is a mind blowing 100, so you know it's super clean!
author: Ann L.

description: The tacos are excellent at this taco truck. The meat is very tender and flavorful and the balance of tortilla, meat, onions and cilantro really makes the flavor come alive. On my last visit the pollo was juicy, tasty and not dry. The carnitas was also quite spectacular - just hopping with flavor. If you are in the area and don't mind the lines, definitely grab the 3 tacos for $5, it is well worth it.
author: Dom L.

description:
Hang over cure? Lol 

People just go here for location. Hard to find a good mexican spot in Embarcadero. This truck is pricey. Expect to pay $8 for a super.  Decent meat, not the best. The meat is my only complaint, i guess. Dry? During lunch time the line gets pretty long so try to go there right before 12pm. The super tacos are huge but then again you probably need like 3 slices of lime to drench over the dryness of the meat (carne asada).
author: Jeff C.

description: Pretty sure this place gave me food poisoning. Unlike everyone else here I am a Mexican and a cook myself. The lines for this place make you think it's all that...then you realize your in San Francisco, where folks simply have no clue the depth, diversity and what to look for in mexican food. Granted this is just a truck, street food. But there are some basics you look for, is the meat marinated, moist? is there a lot of fat? Is the salsa fresh? They seem to have turned down the volume to cater to their clientele. Good news for SF is that a Rosa Mexicana just opened on Steuart st in Embarcadero. Sadly this is a DC/NY restaraunt chain !! But they have dishes there you simply cannot find in SF restaraunts which cater to the taco/nacho/margarita crowd
author: Armando Z.

description: The Best burritos this side of Mission street. You consume an entire meal for under 6 bucks. Wait until 1:30 if you can and the lunch line will die down. The salsa is also own the house. Holy frijoles!!
author: Bruce B.

description:
HEAVEN!!!!  

PERFECTION! Best burrito in all of San Francisco, if not the world. 

The chicken here is so, so, so delicious I can't handle it! The problem at some tacquieras is that sometimes the meat is fatty or gristly, but the Taco Truck meat is immaculate!!! And their salsas (especially the red) are out of this world.  Nothing is better than snagging a burrito here and then walking over to the Embarcadero and picnicking with a view of the Bay Bridge. This place is amazing!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
You have no idea how excited I was to find this gem across the street from my office.  They set up shop around 11AM, and stay open until about 3PM.  Their menu includes tacos, burritos and quesadillas filled with veggies, chicken, tongue, beef or carne asada, and they have a vegetarian option!  Once a week I order their regular sized, vegetarian burrito filled with white rice, lettuce, black beans, cheddar cheese, and guacamole.  I always order their hot salsa, which is a spicy, flavorful chipotle salsa (not just hot for hots sake).  

When you arrive at the corner of Spear and Folsom at lunchtime, you'll find a huge line and an even larger crowd of patrons waiting for their orders.  What you won't find, are angry faces.  This place is well worth the wait (the longest wait for me was 15 minutes) and everything is always fresh, whether you order at peak lunch time, or not.  

Hope to see you in line sometime!
author: Lacey H.

description: The carne asada was over seasoned, meat was just okay.  I guess I've been spoiled by Three Brothers in Palo Alto.  But if SF is your only spot, then this will do.  Just expect long lines during lunch.
author: Ivan D.

description:
I got a burrito today when the truck was at the G-food lounge on 2nd Street.

The quality of the burrito was very good, and it was quite tasty.  However the burrito was so small it left me hungry.   This burrito was the size of a child's burrito. I expect more for $8.
author: Doug S.

description:
I don't know who started the trend of obnoxious burritos... but I'm sure glad that this place doesn't follow that trend. There are way too many burrito joints that make burritos the size of footballs just to get some hype. . They make the perfect sized burrito here... not too fat, not too short, but just right.

As far as taste... this truck ranks up there with the some of the best that the Mission has to offer.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: It's so hard to find a taco truck in the Embarcadero area. So my co-worker told me about this truck on Spear/Folsom. So I went and tried it and it was pretty decent tacos. You get 3 soft tacos for $5. Any extra taco is $2.  I really like their beef tacos. I have also tried their beef tongue taco which was very tender. The only thing that I don't like was their carnitas, because it was very oily. I just don't know how much oil can you put on that taco shell. The oil soaks through my paper plate whenever I ordered carnitas tacos. Nevertheless, I usually just ordered beef or beef tongue. Also their mega taco for $6 is pretty good too. I have yet to try their burritos, but I am sure is good since many people order it.
author: Elaine C.

description: Great tacos, great burritos, what more can you ask for? Their carnitas is good, not dry like many places and their al pastor is even better.
author: Dave T.

description: Delicious super taco! I'm glad I only ordered one, not realizing how super it actually was. It's basically like a burrito bowl from Chipotle, with a tiny little taco tortilla at the bottom. There's actually really no point in the tortilla, since it can in no way handle the massive amount of meat, cheese, sour cream, rice, beans, etc that's on top of it, but I do enjoy my carbs. I got the carne asada without beans and it was yummy!
author: Jacqueline K.

description: Damn fine burritos! I will miss you guys when you have to move out of your usual lot!
author: Cody W.

description:
While the meat is not as tasty as La Taqueria, it's still pretty damn good.  

I recommend the $1.50 taquitos (3 is enough for lunch for me) - carnitas and el pastor are both good.  You need to order 2 but how anyone can eat just one I don't know.  The taquitos come with sliced radishes, pickled carrots, and pickled peppers of some kind (banana pepper type spicy but long and green).

I haven't tried the burrito yet, but having peeked around at everyone elses, I'm not convinced enough to convert from the taquitos.

Be prepared to wait.  I arrived around 12:20 and there were 15 people in line in front of me as well as another 5-10 waiting around for their food.  In the end it took about 10 min to get through the line and then another 10 to get my food.  Bring a friend or some reading material.
author: Jean K.

description:
What I had: Carne Asada Super Burrito

They give you all the ingredients, including guacamole, which is included without extra fee. Pretty cheap. I didn't find it that special though. I'm fine with just getting Chipotle. I hope I didn't offend anyone... I'm not a Mexican food connoisseur.
author: Vera W.

description: It isn't amazing, but what do you expect? It scratches that greasy-not-qyite-authentic-mexican-food itch that everybody knows they have sometimes.. The guys in the truck are nice and patient, food is made quickly, and it doesn't break the bank!
author: Haak S.

description:
Got there at 11:45 to beat the lunch crowd with a group of friends. Its also nice to get there early so you can get a small table.

I had the carne asada regular burrito. It was too much food for me. Next time i think i'll just grab the 3 soft tacos. flavors were there and i loved how they added bits of the beef fat to really give it some flavor. it was the good beef.

i will come again and i will try their entire menu. its nice to have something healthy and good.
author: KK M.

description:
This taco truck is amazing.

I always pass by this place when going to other restaurants off the embarcardero and I would tell myself that "next time", I would try it out. After a few weeks of "next times", I finally went. The long line was a good sign, especially since it was 12:15, the time when hungry office people come out to feed.

I decided to get 2 spicy chicken taco  and 1 spicy pork taco for the grand total of $4.50. And for good measure, I got some chips to hold me over while I waited for my food. The chips were yummy and the mild green salsa I got was delicious, although I managed to spill all the salsa in the bag of chips later on. After a good 10 minute wait, I got my food and walked down to the embarcardero to enjoy my lunch. Between the pork and the chicken, I definitely enjoyed the pork a bit more, mostly because the chicken was really oily and didn't have as much flavor as the pork. But I vowed to return. For the pork.

It's not the best taco in the whole world, that award goes to the taquerias in San Diego and Mexico, but for the area, it's pretty darn goood.
author: Viola L.

description:
This is a truck.  They serve tacos.  It doesn't get any simpler than that.  There's beauty in that simplicity.

Yes, the menu is limited, and that is a good thing.  It is not a restaurant, it is not a burrito joint, it is not a hole-in-the-wall or even a shack.  I can dig the fact that this taco truck will never aspire to be anything more than a taco truck, nor does it ever need to. 

You come to this truck for tacos or burritos and you can choose between chicken, steak, pork and lengua.  As for salsa, you have two options: spicy or mild, and they apply it for you.  I have to applaud the people who run this operation for making it so efficient and so simple.  As a bonus, you will get pickled peppers and carrots and radishes with your food.  To me, that shows that this truck is legit.  They weren't the best three tacos I've ever had, but I can easily think of far worse ways to spend $4.50.  Los Compadres on wheels has taken the quintessential taco eating experience and kept it in it's purest form.  You can appreciate it, or you can get the hell out and cry to your nachos bellgrande.

So if you're in the area, and are craving an authentic taco experience, don't fear the taco truck.  Just pretend that all the dudes in business suits are actually hard-laboring caballeros...
author: Tim C.

description: Ummm . . . Yes, please!! It definitely doesn't help that I can see the line forming every lunch hour from my office.  San Francisco has so much to offer with respect to Mexican food, but if you want fresh, reasonably priced, and super flavorful Mexican food in the SOMA, Los Compadres is perfect. I've tried the tacos (pollo and carne asada), and the quesadilla. All with the spicier sauce (which is amazing).  They also have burritos and I will definitely be back to try one!
author: Nadia S.

description:
Fast, cheap, and easy--I'm in love!

When I have to pay for my lunch, I like to tap Los Compadres for a $7.50 super burrito with carnitas. It has all the fixins' plus a nice kick. Actually the firm bought me a burrito here once, and it tasted even better than usual because it was fantastically free.

The first time I went to the truck it was after 12p and I had to wait 45 minutes. The second time it was 11:30 and the wait was 10 minutes. Here's time-saving tip: Go before the noon rush.

I love eating at nice restaurants, but at times I just want something huge and heavy to hit the spot--you know, underneath my seven fat rolls. =)
author: Liz T.

description:
I'm comparing this to my beloved El Taco de Oro in Alviso.

The carnitas burrito (with spicy sauce is a must) I had was a solid 4 star burrito.  Not huge, like many burritos you'll encounter at taco trucks, but not tiny enough to leave you hungry, it was definitely the right size.  With a good amount of cilantro, sauce, meat, black beans, and rice, I couldn't complain about anything but the dryness of it.  Not sure how this would be remedied without going too overboard on the spicy sauce.


I also had a lengua taco, which I compared directly to my ETdO benchmark.  While good, it still doesn't come near to the standard.  Some lengua pieces were too chewy and the sauce/taste of the entire taco wasn't as savory as ETdO.  The taco itself is a 3 star taco, which averages the overall rating to around a 3.5.  

I have yet to try the other meats, as the price for this and ETdO are the same, however, the lack of cabeza may lower this rating to just a 3 star in the future.
author: Jeff N.

description: I come here often, it's near my office. I imagine in total I've probably been here more than 30 times. The food is OK, not bad, but not good either. I'd recommend coming to this place only if you work nearby and have a hankering for some average Mexican food (there aren't any other nearby walkable options). Ultimately, there are so many taquerias (both mobile and not) that are significantly better than this place that I wouldn't recommend coming here for any other reason. Don't be deceived by the long lines, you're not going to get anything memorable here. If you have a car, go elsewhere. If you have a bus pass, go elsewhere. If you're stuck in the office, this place will do.
author: Russ N.

description:
Agree with all the comments re - "best tacos ever" - no equal in terms of the tacos (carnitas, pastor, lengua all excellent)

would skip the quesidallas and burritos are ok -

top it off with a vietnamese coffee (in the coffee wagon next door!)
author: Ben P.

description:
Just read some of these other reviews, people.  Does this sound like an over-hyped gut-truck swarming with Yelpers to you?  Because it is.  

Salsa, no bueno.  Mushy, flavorless tomatoes and not enough of the good stuff.  I fear the bacteria count in such salsa and recommend getting your burrito without it because I don't want to see you get dysentery or something. 

The al pastor was just OK but nothing I'd wait for again; I could get down to Cancun on 6th and Market in that amount of time.  

At least it was big.  I finished it, but regretted it.
author: Jared L.

description:
The Legua is great.  On a warm day the line can get a little out of hand.  M
I still think this is one of the best tacos in the city.

On a side note.  It isn't cool to hold a place in line for 4 of your friends.  You know who you are.
author: Nopadon W.

description:
I have always been weary of mobile food places, especially taco trucks. I have a fear that once I order a burrito and I get my order, all warm and nice, and then open it only to realize that instead of my burrito they just gave me a brick wrapped in tinfoil, but when I turn around to discuss this minor oversight they would have already sped away BECAUSE THEY'RE IN A FUCKING MOTOR VICHICAL! Then I would be left standing their with a brick wrapped in tinfoil when I really have a craving for just that, except instead of the brick it would be a burrito, and instead of tinfoil there would be a puppy that totally wants to be friends, but instead of that I would just have a damn brick wrapped in damn tinfoil. This is one of my biggest fears, right in front of my fear of not getting over my problem with having irrational fears. 

That's why I approach mobile food stands cautiously, which is how I approached the Los Compadres Taco Truck., like a baboon.... A SAFETY BABOON!!! (if yelp reviews allowed to have pictures I would insert a picture of a baboon in a safety helmet and a crossing guard uniform). But there are always a few signs of reassurance that the business will not just take off and fee to peddle more bricks to other unsuspecting consumers. Such as a flat tire, or a push cart operated by someone who didn't look that healthy and probably couldn't push/run that fast, or me siphoning the gas from their gas tanks. Though Los Compadres did not have any of these, it did have a stable location where I've never seen the truck move from since I started working in the city. I still wanted to slash the tires just to be safe, but I decided against it.

I was there early for lunch (around 11:45) but there was already a line there, so I begrudgingly got in line and reopened the option of deflating a tire. I ordered the lengua regular burrito, which was kinda pricey for a taco truck. I handed over the money suspiciously, like an antelope.... A DETECTIVE ANTALOPE!!!  (use your imagination).

As I got my number I made sure I gave them a look that conveyed the message "you better be cooking meat on that grill and not a brick, because bricks aren't food at all it's building material (or food for rock monsters I guess) BUT DEFINITELY NOT FOOD FOR HUMANS!!!" I think the cook got my message exactly because he scribbled something on the order paper, which I assume said something like "Not a Rock Monster". 

Once I got my burrito unwrapped and took a few test bites to make sure it wasn't a brick or have traces of brick like material in there, I started to fully enjoy my order. The meat had just the right texture that allowed all the ingredients to mix well in the mouth, and a little bit of spice to provide an extra kick. It wasn't too salty or too bland and each bite was just like a fiesta in my mouth (and no one invited that weird kid no one likes). 

Overall it was a very good burrito, without any trace of physical construction material, but there was plenty of metaphorical construction material, building a bridge to my heart. The only downside was the higher than usual price for a taco truck and the smaller than usual size of the burrito relative to other taquerias, then again you can't really humor the idea of slashing the tires on other taquerias.
author: Youchen W.

description:
Tasty super tacos.  Great burritos.  Always a line.
100 percent on the cleanliness report.
I work nearby and it's my comfort food.
Sure, you'll be sleepy in the afternoon if you eat the whole burrito.
The Al Pastor is spicy and greasy and really good.
I don't understand the negative reviews, except maybe they're from people who don't want it to get more crowded than it already is.
And they blast indie rock playing from an iPod while you wait.
Super cool truck that I've gotten lunch from many, many times.
author: Kev M.

description: I can't help it, I love food. Earlier this week I ate my brought-from-home lunch and was still hungry, so I ordered lunch #2 at Los Compadres - a carnitas quesadilla with guac - and it was delicious. The salsa was spicy and added the right amount of kick. I'd definitely come back and try other items on the menu, and I'll probably come back soon since it's a stone's throw away from my office (such a dangerous place to work for someone with an inner fat kid). Prices are a tad expensive for Mexican, but everything's expensive in the city, especially in the Embarcadero.
author: Bella L.

description: I love the al pastor super taco.  It's a nice amount of food for $6.  You can walk to the water and enjoy your lunch with views of the bay.  Can't beat it!  It's a great escape from the office on a nice day.
author: Stephanie R.

description: Its been a while since I ate here last. I went today and have a less enthusiastic review. Unfortunately the burrito now has less flavor. But the biggest difference is the burrito is about an inch and a half in diameter. Tiny. I just finished one and I'm still hungry. Its too bad, I guess I need to find a new burrito in the neighborhood.
author: Mike R.

description:
Awesome lunchtime spicy vegetarian burrito fix!

The truck was missing from the corner for weeks in late December & early January. It's back, now.
author: Mars H.

description: Excellent food. I had this place prepare catering trays of make-your own tacos for a large party and the food was delicious and was reasonably priced.
author: marc c.

description:
I was really hoping that the food was as good as all the reviews said but I was disappointed...so disappointed smh. :/

I come from Mexico so I know good Mexican food vs imitation food. And I have you know one quick fact burritos are non existent in Mexico, they're Tex-Mex. 

So here are the facts from my order:
Order: Carne Asada regular burrito with green salsa; 
Price: $6 even
Review: I found the meat dry, probably from sitting too long or being overcooked
The pinto beans had no flavor
Rice was okay, but pretty bland
The green salsa, well it was no where in sight

If your looking for authentic Mexican food with some flavor this isn't it and they charge for extra salsa and the burritos need it... desperately. I ate about 1/4 of the burrito before tossing it out and I dislike wasting my money like that.
author: Myra E.

description: Very blah...From all the good reviews I expected way more from this taco truck. I was craving Mexican food, but my craving wasn't satisfied sadly. I had the super taco with carne asada. I don't think they flavor their meats (perhaps I chose the wrong kind of meat?) well so overall it did not have an exciting flavor. On top of that, the salsa did not taste fresh...neither was the lettuce in my super taco. I barely remember having guacamole in my taco and I definitely didn't taste the cheese even though i saw mozzarella cheese in it. I asked for spicy and it did not taste a bit spicy...even though many reviewers mentioned "when they say spicy, they mean it." I probably won't come back unless I am dying for some Mexican.
author: Cindy L.

description:
I begged to differ here but I'm new to the area and had a few burritos and  tacos at this place but his place is nothing to write home about.
