Overpriced for just an average tacos truck food. The steak burritos have some nasty after taste that a cold beverage could not wash away. The super and regular burritos are practically the same. I would expect the super burritos would come more with salsa but non-whatsoever. No chip that comes with it. With 7.50 for a super burrito, it is overpriced compare to any other truck that are out there. The tacos also lack additional salsa. It was dry and average at best. The only good thing is the location is very close to my work.
author: Derek S.

description:
The. Best. Burritos. Hands-down.
$5.50 for a full meal (which can easily be split into lunch and dinner!) near the Embarcadero is unheard of.
Just be forewarned: if you can wait until ~1:30/2:00 for lunch, you should wait. Otherwise, the noon-ish wait times can easily take up half your lunch hour. (I love peaking down at the taco truck from my 7th floor office window - I'd know exactly when the lines are dying down) :-)
author: Jill T.

description:
The Truck!!! The lines can get ridiculous for lunch. You either have to go early or late. I always scope it out from the office window before deciding to go. 

I didn't realize what a great taco truck they were until I ate my way through the mission. The flavors are fresh, all the meat taste great. It's super delish. 

Also, they're probably one of the cleanest eating establishments in the city. They always rate 100 from the health department. That's hard to do!
author: Thanya S.

description:
AKA El Toyanese taco truck.

I've heard about the taco truck within walking distance of the FiDi for a long time but it's only recently that I've added Los Compadres to my lunch list, now that  friend works only a block away.  The first thing I noticed was how good the flour tortilla tasted.  Usually the flour tortillas are pretty forgettable, if noticed at all.  This was a decent flour tortilla.  Their al pastor was tasty, although I can't tell whether it's roasted on a spit or it's just marinated pork bits that are grilled up like everything else.  Their carne asada is also juicy and flavorful.  The corn tortillas for their tacos are not greasy like at the hard core taco trucks.  That could be a plus or minus depending on what your preference is.  It's nice for lunch though because I don't have to deal with greasy fingers or splotches all over my shirt.

Cilantro haters beware, they throw some in on their cheese quesadilla.  I thought it made it taste a million times better than your standard quesadilla and will have to start adding cilantro to my quesadillas at home.

For your basic tacos, burritos, and quesadilla this is going to be my spot from now on at lunch time.
author: Luis M.

description: Big fan of Los Compadres, I live right across the street from there and it's a great value and a great meal. You can't beat the 3 tacos for $5. There burritos are nothing spectacular, but their chips & salsa are great. There's always a long line so I recommend getting there at 10:50am, they open at 11am sharp. They even have a few tables and chairs so you can eat by the truck if it's nice outside. I recommend the carne asada & carnitas tacos above the pastor, chicken or lengua.
author: mehul p.

description: I used to work down the street from the truck. I already miss it. Good stuff. Can't go wrong with any of the burrito choices or tacos.
author: El T.

description:
I  had heard good things about this truck.
I got in line.  I chose to order a simple chicken burrito. 
I asked the guy taking orders VERY CLEARLY if I could have it without cilantro.  To make sure I was covering my bases, I asked if the salsa had cilantro or if the chicken might be marinated in it, or if the guacamole had any in it.  He answered "NO" on all counts.  I was very very clear that I did not want cilantro in any part of my burrito.

So I ordered it.

And you know what I got?  

A burrito INFECTED with tons and tons of cilantro.

This place is close to where I work, but I'd rather just walk the mile to Orale Orale.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
I'm pretty sure if my coworkers read this, I will be expelled from my place of work. Los Compadres is less than a block away and everybody's favorite.

Everybody except me!

As pros, it's cheap and really quick.

As a negative, it's too spicy for me (I have a bland palate OK?!) and the al pastor is greasy....

I prefer Mexico Au Parc or even Maya.
author: Eli B.

description:
This is about the best you can get for a Taco Truck and definitely the best burrito in the area.  The plain old grilled chicken burrito with black beans rocks, great spice and flavor.  The tacos are also very tasty, especially the carnitas!  Very consistent.

Get there before 12 and all the CNET/CBSers!
author: Christopher P.

description:
EDIT: OMG OMG OMG, after scarving down 3/4 of my burrito, i JUST found a freakin EYELASH IN MY STINKIN BURRITO.. *gag*

***

{again, wordy review, but c'mon folks, ya know how i roll} =o

10/4/07 LUNCH
the perks in working at the place i'm at, i have such easy access to the FiDi/SOMA.

LA folks: please, i need some love and some pity ... you'd think i was in for a REAL SOLID treat coming to a taco truck for some BOMB ASS burritos...

for ALL: i am biased, i am from LA, forgive me, but forget me not, i am spoiled by LA standards, so mind me.

let's just say, i'm ok, not content, not filled with joy, but ok. for $5 i got myself a burrito, daydreaming about LA... 

-1 not having my horchata.. WTH? what taco truck in CALI only carry soda and water? BOO...
-1 no tapatio? (the guy looks at me and says, "we never carried that before")
-1 having it in an area where they are doing construction, who KNOWS what kinda dust particles or what not went in my food while MAKING my burrito, but i'll cancel this out by giving it neutral because they wrapped my burrito so tight, kinda reminded me of those kimbap style...
-1 you have to PURCHASE CHIPS? wow, mebe i AM spoiled by LA.
-1 you HAVE TO GET A MINIMUM OF 2 taquitos/tacos if you want to buy one. SO UNHEARD OF IN LA... not that it costed a lot, but sometimes you just want one. 
-1 oh, i also wanted to get a sope, and the guy in front says, "oh we dont ahve that..." (boink! then why is written on the bus dummy)

i swear i was prolly asking for MORE mexican food than i should've...

ok, so for the +.

+1 all prices are included w/tax 
+1 reasonable prices (no more than $5 tops)
+1 fast moving line... it may seem like it will take forever, but once you order, you prolly wait max 10 minutes, but idk if this is a good concept or not, but anywys, they give you a #, and you wait, and then, the guy calls out like 5 #s at a time.
+1 they got an award for being clean, you know, those grading scale ratings LA has at every restaurant, well, they got a 100.

if you know me, i'm all about cleanliness when it comes to food...

anyways, the wait was ok, and there's quite a number of soma/fidi monkeys waiting patiently, and in the end, i have to say, food was good ...  peek fotos.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
YES TAQUITOS. The little tacos are DELICIOUS. and they are not the horrible abomination that Taco Bell calls a taquito, these are just small soft corn tortilla tacos, with meat, salsa, onions and cilantro and nothing else to get in the way, except maybe a squeeze of lime juice. At $1.50 a pop, they are affordable in BULK, too. Get about 4 of these and a coke then head down to the Embarcadero = perfect lunch. I suggest the al pastor, the grilled chicken is a little too plain.  I'll have to come back to try the carnitas. Also, consider hitting this place up a little bit later than the usual lunch hour, because the line can get pretty long during lunch rush.

p.s. if you come to this location looking for the El Tonayense taco truck, if you look at the front of this truck, you can faintly make out where there used to be letters spelling out "El Tonayense", so I think there was a name change at one point.
author: Tom H.

description:
I agree with most of the low reviews here. 

Four years ago, I used to think that this place was "the best." But after eating other at other Taco Trucks (like El Tonayense), I know better. 

Over the last four years, this place has increased its prices by $2 for a burrito (I remember when I could get a burrito for $5 here and when the super taco was truly 'super'). I would stay away from the pollo asado here as I have found numerous bone chunks/rocks in my burritos. 

Unfortunately, this is the only taco truck in the SoMA area so most of us enjoy the allure of a taco truck in downtown. However, poor quality meats, a long wait (I can see the truck from my desk so if we do eat here we try to arrive before 11:45 or after 12:45 to beat the rush at noon which would cause us to literally wait 20 minutes for a burrito). 

Sorry, Los Compadres. I've had better at taco trucks in the Mission and I do not appreciate the $2 inflation combined with degradation of product and increase in wait-time over the last four years. You will always have a special place in my heart, but not because of the sweet oils from your burritos.

By the way, a close, better alternative, is the burrito place in the Rincon Center.
author: Mark S.

description:
Yes, everything Patrick E. said.  Burritos are served HOT, and they are well constructed. 

I don't like how they charge for their hot sauce though.
author: shaun l.

description:
Ok, so I have not actually been here myself, but everyone at my work goes here for lunch and they love it. They all say its the best lunch ever. And the boys who run this stand are super nice.

Hi George!

So go here! Eat well for your buck! And never underestimate the power of a good taco truck!
author: Cat R.

description:
This is the closest decent Mexican near my work place. 

I live in the Mission and am picky about my Mexican food; I give them 4 stars for the food.

I almost always get the carnitas...and it tastes a little different each time. I love seeing how the carnitas will be...crispy or more tender.  I've had the carnitas in the super taco and the burritos.  As one other reviewer commented, the super taco is not just a taco.  It's a box filled up with all sorts of goodness.

I've had better lengua in the Mission, so I don't recommend that.

I was just commenting to my friend today that the place would be so perfect if they opened a beer garden in the parking lot as well.

Oh, that last star: it's for all the eye candy while waiting for my carnitas.
author: Sooj O.

description:
This is not the best Al Pastor in the City - that title is currently held by Balazo in the Haight(!?!)  (IMHO). But:

This is my favorite Al Pastor Burrito in the entire City. 

This is the best taqueria in the entire FiDi. And it's not even close. But consider:

This taco truck is always clear of people from the window in your office, but packed once you finally make it there. Which sucks because:

This is a slow moving line. And:

This is probably not where you want to go on Friday if you went out Thursday night, and maybe you're a wee bit hungover. Because:

This is the third worst example of sidewalk etiquette. (Nothing holds a candle to the self-satisfied clientele at Tartine, or the oblivious post dinner ice cream eaters at Bi Rite Creamery). But:

This is the best taco truck I've eaten at in the City. (So far - suck it El Tonayense near Best Buy! Your shit is bland.)
author: Olu J.

description:
So I read a couple of reviews on Yelp about the "Taco Truck". I make some frequent emergency trips down to the Colo at 365, and most of the time, our paths cross.  

On Thursday, as I was departing from the Colo, I was HUN-GRY! Skipped breakfast (that's bad kids, definately a big no-no!) and it was almost 1:45pm! I proceeded to "The Taco Truck" since there was only a couple of people waiting in line.

When I got there, they were just waiting for their food, so I stared at their menu for a couple of mins. Picture two small, white sheets of paper taped on the truck with ultra small fonts... Yeah..

Whenever I go to a Mexican place, whether that's a full-fledged, sit my ass down restaurant or a walk up restaurant like this one, I always order one thing: THE SUPER BURITTO. Just like my obsession with "Chicken Teriyaki", without gauging the "common" food, its hard to tell how good a restaurant is...

Not only does it have beans, cheese, meats and salsa, but with the SUPER in front of it, which means that they'll add some guacamole, onions and cliantro to it and you got a delicious meal good to go.

Yum-O!!

I got a carna asda super burrito for $5.50. Popped 50 cents in the tip jar for good karma and BAM! My # 52 was called about 5 mins later and I got a HUGE ass burrito, wraped in foil and a paper plate for easy portability.

Got back to the office and it was still hot. Good job! I unveiled IT to my fellow co-workers and they wondered where I got it. I had to tell them, but even so, the burrito could NOT be finished in 1 sitting. Simply too much meat, not that much beans and a lot of salsa (I LIKE Salsa)

So today, I wrapped up the burrito, popped it in the microwave and tried it again, expecting it would suck.  But it did not suck. It still was filled with the mouth-watering spices and had lotsa FLAVA!

I'd definately go back for sure and try their tacos. I for one, love Taco Trucks! For that reason along, I wrote a small haiku just for you..

Here's a haiku written in 5-7-5 form:
Your big "Taco Truck"
At the parking lot corner
Mexican food good!
author: Wilson L.

description:
Jury still out on this place.  The price is right.  The food is inconsistent and the line can be really long.

I prefer the burritos to the tacos. WAY too many onions on the tacos, but WAY too much rice in the burrito.  Spicy is really hot so be careful.  That said, I find the al pastor and carnitas to be quite tasty.  A little sour cream and guac go a long way.

If they balanced out the ingredients a little better and they'd be fine.
author: Tom R.

description:
Great lunch for very little cash! $4 for a super taco and it' s not your ordinary taco. It's a to-go container filled to the top with corn tortillas, your choice of meat (I prefer carne asada), guac and the usual fixings. I like spicy food, but holy spicy! The hot sauce is HOT! I try to go during off-peak times so I don't get stuck in the 10-20 minute wait. 

Definitely worth a go if you work in the area.
author: Defne A.

description:
Hey if you're into cheap burritos with plenty of cilantro (like me) then this is the place oops...I mean truck for you!

The line can get kinda long during lunch but hey at least you're out of the building getting some sun and fresh air.  No complaints here.

I usually stick with the carne asada regular burrito and have tried the "super" variety but I don't see much difference for the additional dollar or so.  I've ventured out and tried the al pastor which was OK.

I always order a side of their hot salsa for an extra 50 cents its muy caliente!!
author: TobikoJoe S.

description:
My friend eats here every day.  He gets a Veggie Burrito at around 11:15am literally 4 out of 5 days/week.

He convinced me to overcome my taco truck fears and get a burrito here.  I've now been back 4 or 5 times.  It's nice to know that they get a 100 score on their health inspection.  It is clean, and the fact that it's off the ground (on wheels) probably helps keep pests away.

The selection is somewhat limited, but they have the basics.  Certainly not as tasty as Pancho Villa, but it's quick, the price is right, and it's a decent burrito.
author: Bill V.

description:
Oh sweet Taco Truck of life. 
Carnitas Super Taco. Addictive. Delicious. Exquisite. Authentic. Cheap.
I had it once and went back at least twice a week for the next month. 
This is the Mexican food I dream about when I'm not near it.
author: Terika B.

description:
Super burrito, spicy, with chicken = yummmmmmy

waiting on a crowded corner in windy SOMA = brrrrrrr

yummy (greater than) brrrrr = Taco Truck wins!

ps: Yelp, really? I can't insert a greater than symbol?? Lame.
author: Maryam S.

description:
Being from So Cal, it was hard to find a really good taco truck in the city.  I know, everyone says to hit up the Mission...but, nothing really impressed my highly-delicate palate.  Until now...

Los Compadres Taco Truck in SoMa...I've tracked you down and now I'm addicted.  They keep it simple.  Meat, beans, rice, & hot sauce.  The rest you can add to your heart's desire.  Me?  I like it straightforward.  You have hot sauce to die for.  

3-4 on the heartburn scale, but that's a good thing.  Anything less wouldn't be legitimate, anything more would force me to reduce my intake to once a week.  

Venture down the alley...you'll be glad you did...
author: Susan L.

description: I love this place (truck)! I've only had their $6 super tacos even though I've been there several times, it's so good that I don't even want to try anything else. I highly recommend this truck!
author: Kelvin Y.

description: three tacos is the best deal around.  The burrito is a little small for how much it costs and these guys cannot for the life of them figure how not to force all the guac & sour cream into the ends of the burritto rather than have everything evenly distributed throughout the wrap which in my estimation seems to be an art rather than as simple as it sounds.  A solid go to for lunch but get there early or you will be waiting...
author: Jon W.

description:
For a roach coach, it's pretty good. 

For cheap Mexican food in the FiDi, it rocks. It's a bit of a hike from where I work, but worth the journey, on a nice day. 

Been there twice and haven't been disappointed yet. Both times had the carne asada Super B. I was expecting the meat and rice to be crunchy, but was pleasantly surprised when both were fresh and full of flavor. Six bucks for the super burrito and it's way better than it's closest competitor, Chiptole. 

Definitely a long line around lunch time, but they're usually johnny-on-the-spot with the service. 

The guys working the truck are always nice and word on the streets is they received an A from the health dept. No worries about receiving an actual roach with your food.
author: Andrew A.

description: Super Soft Taco with meat, beans, and salsa of your choice, guacamole, sour cream, and cheese on two soft corn tortillas.  For $6 bucks, it's a solid option for a take-out lunch.  Lines are always long at the lunch hour rush, so go at 11:30 or after 1ish to avoid the crowds and wait.
author: Kalista W.

description:
Once we figured out where to order (It's a little window about a foot above my head), everything was GREAT.  I had 3 carnitas tacos that were very tasty.  The meat was tender in parts, crunchy in others and tasted fantastic.  My wife had 3 different tacos and liked them all.  The salsas were just OK.  

Since they were street style Mexican, they really aren't much different than what I get in Dallas at Fuel City.  The only difference is that I get some radish slices.  In Texas we get some extra sautéed onion slices.  Both are good, just different.  We did get some chips that tasted a little stale.  The tacos were great and the burritos looked really good and big, but we didn't get any.  

It is funny seeing the looks you get walking through the lobby of a very nice hotel on the Embarcadero with a plate of taco truck food!  The other guests looked at us like we were eating their dog, but the people at the front desk asked what we had and gave us a big smile and a thumb's up!
author: Brian B.

description:
I can see this place from the window of my 9th floor cubicle...I picked up a burrito at around 11:10 when there was no line. Now it's around 11:50 and I can see about 15 to 20 people milling about. I think the crowds flock to this roach coach on the corner because it's really the only decent burrito to be had in the area. DECENT is the key word here. Clearly the place called "Pepe's Taqueria" at the nearby Rincon Center is just god awful gut bomb served up to people who don't know any better!

Today's burrito session had me eating the super burrito with carne asada and whole beans. I always ask for salsa on the side because their pico de gallo is way too heavy on the cilantro for my taste. I tend to be a big carnitas guy and it bums me out that their carnitas can sometimes be hard and dry...seriously...dried out, almost like eating pork jerky! Go with the carne asada or pastor and you'll be in good shape.

Not the best burrito in town, certainly not the worst. This will always be my workday burrito - unless La Taqueria opens a restaurant nearby!
author: Nate R.

description:
This place is great for a truck.  They have places to sit right beneath the window, decent food, and are situated a block away from the gorgeous embarcadero...minus that damn arrow in the ground, it's such a great spot to nap after this truck's food (on a sunny day of course).

As far as taqueria food goes, it's just ok for me.  I got their lengua tacos, because for me, if a taqueria doesn't have good lengua, they just don't serve good food...period.  And I was seriously underwhelmed.  The chunks were way too big, allowing me to get a true glimpse of what I was eating...taste buds as all, and it was chewy and not flavorful(normal lengua is to die for...).  

Aside from my tongue gripe, I feel as though it's a good spot.  I have gotten their carnitas, no complaints, their chicken tacos, eh-kinda bland...and I have been wanting to go back for their al pastor taquitos, but I haven't made the trip..weather has been a bit too ominous as of late.  

This is however one of the first taco trucks that doesn't make me nervous (a la truck outside of kaiser on geary and divis), they seen extremely clean...from what I can see over their high counter tops...

muchas gracias a los compadres, en realidad, la comida que sirven es la mejor comida mexicana en SOMA! Ole! :-)
author: Kristin E.

description:
After a long walk from New Montgomery down to the water and back, I happened to run across the "truck".  I questioned for a second if I should cross the street and try it out or just keep walking, but my addiction to Mexican food made me walk the crosswalk!  Uh...I should have just kept walking.  

The menu looked interesting and promising, but it didn't deliver.  My carnitas were like hard crunchy rocks of nothingness.  Not even a bit of salt was recognizable.  I thought I was being safe by getting the carnitas, but I guess I chose wrong.  I also asked for no onions in my tacos but yes on the cilantro and what did I get...heaping spoonfuls of onions and a pinch of cilantro (My bf will not be happy when I get home)  :(  

It was cheap for 3 tacos at $4.50 and there is no tax or SF health surcharge added so that was a plus.  However, I would rather go to my ultimate favorite place for even better tacos and definitely better quality meat for about the same cost.  At least I finally ate at a taco truck so I can cross that off my list of things to do in my life.
author: Ayrn H.

description:
"Hell, it's 11:45am. Let's hurry over to the roach coach before the GAP crowd kills it."

Around the office, that's a typical line when speaking about my favorite taco truck. Or tacqueria, period. No other place can rival their burritos, a hefty lump of meat and cheese and rice and beans, even big enough to feed two people.

And, oh, the place is damn cheap.

Right across the Gap building, on a corner between spear and folsom, the Roach Coach roosts on a crammed parking lot five days a week, from morning to mid afternoon. But if you're not in line before the lunch rush, then you can kiss your appetite goodbye. Frequently, a crowd floods the truck (ostensibly from the adjacent GAP building), sending you packing in line, waiting for a half-hour just to make your order.

Beat the rush and go early. Arriving late isn's a good plan, either, since the roach coach often runs out of meat or rice or chips. When this happen, they over substitute on something, which could be a good or bad thing: See how well your heart and arteries responds when you gorge yourself on a carne asada-laden burrito. . . without the rice and beans. Three pounds of beef. Yum.

But if you like your steak, then El Tonayense fits right up your alley. It's one of the few places where the meat tastes fresh, unlike El Farolito and La Tacqueria, Cancun and San Francisco Taq. Saturated with a special mix of herbs and sauce, the carne asada is perfectly cooked, perfectly cut, and perfectly presented.

Once you take your first bite into the savory burrito, you'll marvel at the level of care placed on its construction. From top to bottom, each section is balanced with the right amount of meat, of guacamole, of beans and cheese. None overpower each other; instead, the ingredients complement each other, giving a subliminal taste with each bite.

The chips, too, serve as equally awesome complement. Only a few tacquerias make their chips, instead relying on prepackaged tortilla chips. El Tonyanese, on the other hand, fries their chips, batters them with salt, and packages them in limited supply. There's a reason why the chips run out around 1pm: they're that good.
author: Richard L.

description:
Thank the gods there's alternative to the fail that is El Faro. Not having worked in this part of the city for many years, I was afraid I would have to put Mexican food lunches aside. Happily, a coworker told me about Los Compadres and their truck full o' win.

I enjoyed a good burrito, very tasty spicy salsa, unstale chips (hello Taqueria Cancun, we're looking at you), and reasonably fast service considering the sizable line.

Los Compadres, you have earned a friend. I'll be back.
author: Mark W.

description:
Real deal tacos, dressed with the typical cilantro, onion, and hot sauce.  The Al Pastor tacos, which were great, were surprisingly not saucy and not that greasy.  The carnitas were very good but didn't have any of the carmalized bits.  Still very good.

Spicy means spicy here, so only say it if you mean it.

They hook you up with a jalapeño, radish coins, and jalapeño pickled carrots  - which are marinated long enough that they are super soft.

3 tacos for $4.50.  Somehow 4 is $6.25.  Fine with me.

Didn't see tortas on their menu.  

Best tacos within walking distance of the Financial District.
author: Dave H.

description:
I am totally down with this taco truck.

Like many people, I thought the idea of a taco truck was super sketchy, until I saw that show on KQED where a small group of people review each others favorite places to eat.  I was shocked when someone picked a taco truck (although I do not think this particular taco truck was the one they reviewed).  They showed the inside of the truck and said that in fact taco trucks are extremely clean and get very high marks on their inspections.  

I walked up to the truck and checked out the menu.  Everything was either $4 or $5, which works for me!  They have a good selection of meats.  I ordered a carnitas super taco, which comes piled with your choice of beans, rice, salsa, guac, sour cream, cheese, letuce, and a lime wedge.  AWESOME.  I was impressed with the quality of the salsa and guacamole--they seemed freshly made and made from ripe tomatos and avocados.  This is my new favorite mexican joint--well, at least in this part of town.
author: Kandi K.

description: Excellent burritos.  Pastor regular burrito with pinto beans spicy definitely hits the spot.  $5.00 is a steal for anything fresh and filling in downtown SF.  Why would people go to Chipotle?  I tried the carne asada once and it's okay.  I usually stick to the Al Pastor (marinated BBQ pork for those who don't speak or understand Spanish)
author: Josh L.

description:
Finally...a good taco near my work (since I can't get 'em anywhere near my home).

I had heard rumors of this taco truck since worked moved to this neighborhood about 2 weeks ago. Figured today was as good as any to try.

3 small tacos, 4.50$. Would be nice if they were a little less expensive, but such is the plight of the city and real estate (even in a small truck). The side of sour cream was huge, and the pico de gallo delicious. I had one of my tacos spicey, and it was right at that good edge of too spicy, which is how I like 'em. Both the pollo and carne asadas were yummers.

Oh, how I wished I had time to go park my butt at the Embarcadero park and watch people while i chowed down. Tomorrow, perhaps!
author: Annie F.

description:
Ahh the legend of the Taco Truck.

Once thought of as trashy food on the side of the road. 
Now...Gourmet. 
Okay lets not get carried away, not gourmet, but sure is delicious!

I have to credit Los Compadres with altering my perception of the Taco Truck.  Up until about a year ago I would have never eaten anything that was served from a giant aluminum-plated box on wheels.

But ever since a co-worker told me that it was something I MUST try, I havent looked back.  

Though the lines are often long (the secret is out) the atomophere (oh yes there is atmophere) is amazing, some days you are at the club, some days you are at a rock concert, which helps pass the time.

The food is always hot and delicious.  I typically go with the chicken taquitos (mini-tacos), but I have also enjoyed their burritos which are a nice size.  The one thing about their burritos is that they dont come with quacamole, which is a must for me.  So make sure to have them add it if you are an avo-adict like me.

I cant say that all Taco Trucks are created equal, but I can say that Los Compadres is the real deal, so if you find yourself in the neighborhood, cruise on up to Los Campadres.
author: Sara Ann S.

description:
I'll eat anything from these guys...it's all delicious.  My co-workers and I make it out here at least once a week.  Current obsession is the $6 super taco: it comes in a box filled with meat, beans, rice, lettuce, guacamole, sour cream, salsa, and cheese.  Fabuloso!  

Bonus points for the really nice service and awesome music blasting from this pimped-out taco truck.  (P.S. Don't you dare hate on the fact that this restaurant has wheels...it's probably cleaner than most of the places you eat at - 100 pt health score!)
author: Krystle S.

description:
Im a Carnivorous Tacosaurus. I am a fan of mobile taco dispensers and my stars are based on the meat. At this place, you gotta be vigilant of the time that you come to get your tacos. If its after 2pm, fogettaboutit. The meat will be fairly dry and overcooked by that time cuz its been sitting in the chaving/heating pans. Go for early lunch and do your stomach and taste buds a favor.

In order of best to worst meats for tacos at this joint (IMO):
1.Pollo Asado
2.Carnitas
3.Al Pastor
4.Lengua
5.Carne Asada

Best deal is the 3 tacos for like $4.50...Get 6!!!
author: Nick V.

description:
My first time at a Taco Truck since moving to the Bay Area, and ironically it happens right across the street from Gap Headquarters.  Huh.

Anyway, as you'd expect from the above statement, this taco truck is larger, newer, and cleaner than most, and offers up some pretty tasty eats.

I went with the super burrito, which includes avacado, sour cream, and a very unique pico de gallo.   For $7.50, it was nicely sized.  But the real kick here was the spice - just warm enough to feel it, but not overwhelming.  It almost had the same kick as certain types of curry which thew me off at first, but once you got used it it  - delicious.
author: John H.

description:
I feel like I write too many 4 star reviews. I like to think it's due to the fact that you have to EARN 5 stars from me, but it can kinda come off as a cop out: "Well I like this place for sure, but dare I bestow 5-star status???" So I take the safe route, and hand out 4 stars. I guess I could go the route of esteemed Yelper Blake W, and give EVERY SINGLE REVIEW 5 stars. Cool? Maybe. Useful? Not so much.

Anyway, I ramble for a reason: Los Compadres, if situated in the heart of the Mission, would be forgettable. Don't get me wrong, it's good, but Christ, it's a burrito joint - unless something is seriously wrong, it's gonna be at least GOOD. But the catch is, this taco truck is literally 50 feet from the front door of my office. It's everything a taco truck should be - no frills, cheap, speedy (unless it's the height of lunch hour), and consistent.

So while Los Compadres would merely be an average 3-star joint, the fact it's so accessible for me easily raises it up a notch. Good stuff.
author: Drew S.

description:
Try The Quesadilla.

The quesadilla (the one with meat, at least - I've never had just the cheese ) is special.   I've had either carnitas or chorizo as my meat choice.  Generous cilantro is included.  The meat to cheese ratio is about 1:1.   Usually I'm a cheese-only kind of gal when it comes to quesadillas, but I think of this as something slightly different from a quesadilla.  It's shaped like a little packet and lightly sliced diagonally - perforated, almost - for easy eating with fingers.  The tortilla has always been grilled perfectly, with that mottling between gold and tan that you see on things that are grilled perfectly.   

I haven't been wowed by the burrito, although with the carnitas as the filling you can't really go wrong.  You could put their carnitas in an old tire and I'd give it at least 3 stars.
author: April D.

description:
SHAME ON ME:

*  for ignoring the warnings of my fellow yelpers and thinking that the super tacos would not be enough to satisfy my hunger.  I certainly did not need the side of chips and salsa.

*  for heeding the warnings of my fellow yelpers and requesting a "mild" order.  I might have enjoyed a bit more kick!

*  for waiting nearly three years before trying out Los Compadres Taco Truck.

*  for daring to leave my desk to grab lunch.  There is work to do!

I will return.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I have been here twice and it has been great both times. I didn't have to wait more than 5-10 minutes either time. I've been there at 12:00 and 12:45. Even if there is occassionally a long wait, I don't understand the complaining. If you know of a good place that doesn't have a long wait, dont attract attention by writing about it on yelp!

I've talked to 3 other people who have been here and they enjoyed the food as well.

The people are also very nice. 

I've only had chicken here, so that's what I can reccommend. Very juicy and flavorful.
author: Richard S.

description:
"The Truck," as it is affectionately known, makes me smile because pretty tasty Mexican food at pretty inexpensive prices equals happiness in my book. I'm lovin' the al pastor (BBQ pork) burritos, chicken and steak tacos, chicken super tacos, plus the chips and salsa.

I should, however, mention the one time I got sick from eating here. It was nothing catastrophic: a few nausious hours compared to the many, many lunchtimes filled with tortilla-wrapped pleasure. (Okay, that sounds gross).
author: Patrick G.

description:
Look, if you are looking for gourmet cuisine (which it sounds like some of the reviews are), then this isn't the place for you.  There is a reason taco trucks have earned the name "roach coach".

That being said, if you want a good, tasty, filling burrito for less than $6, then there isn't any place better.  The truck looks clean (at least from the outside), the guys working are always friendly, and the food tastes great.  I'll admit it can be hit-or-miss sometimes with the carnitas, but I've never had an issue with the carne asada or al pastor.

I'm sure there are probably some places in the Mission that are better, but for a quick lunch at a more than reasonable price, it doesn't get any better than Los Compadres.
author: Matt N.

description:
This is hand's down my second favorite taco truck (1st being Los Compadres at Polk and Hayes) outside of Los Angeles.  

My usual:
Carne Asada Burrito, no arroz, con frioles (beef burrito, no rice, w/ refried beans) & a Mexican Coke!
author: Rod C.

description:
Went here for a quick lunch before heading to Embarcadero.   There was a pretty long line for lunch, and decent reviews, so I gave it a shot.   

Wasnt disappointed, wasnt impressed.    Pretty decent flavors, but I ordered spicy and I didnt even break a sweat.

Good deals if you're in the area, but otherwise, there's better places out there.
author: Ben N.

description:
Not impressed. I could make better tacos.

There are better mexican joints nearby.  

WARNING: NO TAPATIO IN SIGHT. AND HOT SAUCE COSTS YOU 50 CENTS (WTF????) Stinginess at a restaurant is a huge turn-off - especially if it's a friggin taco truck. I mean come on people.

The employees could be friendlier.
author: Chili B.

description: Super burrito, spicy, al pastor is the way to go. It was delicious! Place is busy but they are pretty quick.
author: Larry L.

description:
Clarification: Los Compadres is not the same as El Toyanese that you find over by Best Buy. However, I found out that besides the Spear/Folsom location, they have another truck off of Polk and Hayes.

The food: What can I say? I love, love, love the truck! I frequent this joint at least twice a week - working across the street makes it WAY too easy. Despite the frequency of my visits, I haven't tried most of the menu. "Why?" you ask? Because I can't tear myself away from my usual orders!

Try the Super Taco or the Quesadilla Suiza! Try them with carne asada, carnitas (fried pork, come on), or al pastor.

"...And I would eat them in a boat.
And I would eat them with a goat...

And I will eat them in the rain.
And in the dark. And on a train.
And in a car. And in a tree.
They are so good, so good, you see!"

The catering: Last month, I got the truck to cater a lunch for 75 people at my company. They did a great job. Aside from the usual fixings that they offer at the truck, we also got an assortment of enchiladas that they brought over from their SSF restaurant which totes the same name. Makes me want to venture out there to try the full menu...
author: Amy C.

description:
Really a 3 1/2, The tacos are good, but not great but for downtown it is one of the best deals you can get.  The carne asada is a bit greasy, and the rice they use in the burritos is not all that, but other than that it is pretty good.  The salsa they use is nice and spicy, with good flavor, and the tortillas they use for the tacos are good.

All around solid.

Plus, I ate here once a week for over two years and NEVER got sick or had any problems with the food, so if people are whining about dumb stuff they need to get over it.
author: Nicholas E.

description: The burritos taste OK. They're a little dry and lack any sauce.  For $6 you get a big burrito with meat, beans, and rice. They close at 2:30pm.
author: Brian C.

description: Oh taco truck! Your burrito hits the right spot. Your veggie burrito is yummy.
author: Sherry M.

description:
Taco truck, you are the reason to why I have been jogging so much to lose weight. 

I found this taco truck while I was working at CNET, and as disgusting as it may sound. I once went a whole week, only eating at taco truck. But do you blame me? The burritos here are the best i've ever had, possibly the best i've had in general. 

For the price of a burrito (roughly $7), and the sheer convenience of just walking outside of my building, taco truck i love you.

[APPROVED]
author: Eric T.

description:
Amazing tacos from a taco truck operating out of the parking lot at Spear and Folsom. Walking distance from downtown and parts of SoMA. Absolutely worth the trip. Far better than any I've had in this area.

Steak tacos and chicken tacos are both wonderfully tasty and spicy. And they include a whole radish as a side. It's the perfect balance to the spiciness of the taco.

If this were an indoor sit-down place, I'd give it five stars.
author: Pat T.

description:
OMG! Have to share this.
So we *used to* have a Los Compadres taco truck right near work (over by Pier 39) and my friend and I were the first two people on our floor to try it. It was so good that we raved at a department meeting and soon everyone was going there for their cheap luch fix. 
Sadly the port authority ran them off cuz they were parking in a paid parking lot owned by the port. Now I think that particular truck lingers in the VanNess @ Market area. We tried to drum up an email campaign to get the Port to let them stay but it did no good. *sigh*
author: Rosana M.

description:
I like this place. And compared to Poncho Villa on the warf or the other mexian joint in the ferry building, you're better off going to this place if you like honest/decent prices (dont want to get ripped off) and dont want to be overwelmed with what to order. Obviously its  taco truck, so its down to the basics here. 

My favorites and best deal here: 
Super Taco for $4 - i dont know who came up with this price, but it is a steal considering the amount of food you get. not to mention it is the best super Taco compared to anywhere! it includes choice of meat, rice, lettuce, salsa, guac, sour cream, choice of sauce, pickled jalapenos, radish, limes.. oh god its soo good.. i didnt think you can get stuffed for $4.

The next best thing: Quesadilla a little over $3. Ok, you think  you've had a good quesadilla.. but not liek this place. there's something i really appreciate about simple food thats made right, and it makes a whole difference. 

Try the Tongue when you can - its awsome. 

Reason why it I did not give it a perfect rating - the burritos and regular tacos are just average. 

But order the right thing here, and its 5 stars all the way.
author: Mai T.

description:
These are probably some of the best burritos I've ever had.  I usually get carne asade or the al pastor with black beans, and if I'm being good (which is rare) I only add the guac.  "Super burrito" isn't on the menu anymore, but it's just the regular burrito with all the extras, making it a 7 dollar totally-worth-it lunch.  If you're able to pace yourself and not devour the whole thing in one sitting, the burrito is at least a meal and a half if not two.

A friend noticed these burritos were not as soggy as others, and long and thin instead of short and fat.  This makes the burrito portable, and while you can use a fork/spoon to scoop out the goods like you would an ice cream sundae, utensils are not required.

Get here early (before noon), grab some burritos, walk down a few blocks, sit on the grass and look out at the water.  Relaxing, low key lunch with friends.

Carnitas: Mix of tender pork and chewy, really fried up pork.  Doesn't particularly float my boat, but tastes good.

Salsa hotness: Sometimes I get mild and sometimes I don't, and when it's mild it's spicy and when I ask for spicy it's mild.  I think it's the pico de gallo you can specify spiciness for, but I never know what to expect.  Still, always tasty.
author: Amy N.

description:
First timer at Los Compadres and I must admit I wasn't expecting a food truck at all. When my brother asked me if I wanted to go to a burrito place I thought he meant a restaraunt!

However after eating street meat in NY, Los Compadres wasn't at all intimidating. 

Got here around 11:20am on a Friday for lunch and there were already a couple orders in front of us.

Ordered a carne asada burrito with guac and pico de gallo = $6. I think the best thing about my burrito is it's size. It's not so huge that you will go comatose back in your cubicle. I also did not feel guilty (about the calorie content) after eating this burrito like I usually do after Chipotle. The rice was really good and the meat was juicy. Also the burrito was really hot (temperature wise) which I love because I hate luke warm meals. Even though to add guac and salsa is an extra $0.50 each....the portion was generous and evenly spread (my guac was not all on one side like how some places do it).

I would definitely go back again if I need a burrito fix.
author: Terry D.

description:
One word: AWESOME! Who knew street food from a taco truck could be so good and cheap. The lines tend to be long around Noon so plan accordingly. I ordered a carne asada burrito with black beans and hot sauce so they hand me my burrito after a couple of minutes waiting. As I sit in my office, I totally forgot to get salsa and figured what's done is done so I take a bite and it was one of the best tasting burritos I have had in quite a while. Normally I slather the thing in salsa to give it moisture and believe me when I say it was cooked perfectly -- needing nothing more than extra napkins as you devour the thing. I will be back to try the tacos which I heard are da bomb. 

P.S. Don't be the douche who wants to see the sliced jalapenos to ensure they are cut correctly. People behind you are hungry and your stupid questions only make things worse for everyone. BTW: I know they probably didn't but you never know if they added a little something something to your order for all those wonderfully time wasting questions.
author: S L.

description: warning: this is spicy and it's _no_ joke. I learned that the hard way and I seriously can eat most hot stuff without a problem.  I admit i thought this was a place that served Gap and Google employees "mexican" food.  boy was i wrong.  it's real mexican. The green pepper had me drinking 2 glasses of tap water and 2 glasses of milk! haha. it wasn't funny then. Enjoy but be warned. it's local spicy.  I had the el pastor tacos w/spicy sauce.
author: Emm C.

description: I used to not be a very big fan of Mexican food but ever since my first encounter with the taco truck I have been forever turned...carnitas super burritos will someday be the death of me, but until then, they're like christmas presents all wrapped up in shiny foil and I'm like a little kid waiting to unwrap my gifts.
author: laura q.

description:
I've only tried the burritos so far (~5 visits), and liked the chicken better than carnitas (although it is my favorite usually).  I agree with James J. who said the carnitas wasn't as good as he would have liked. IF the carnitas was better I would eat there every week, because the taco truck is SO close to my work!

Good sized portions for the price.
author: Bob L.

description:
This is some of the best Mexican food I've ever had.  The fact that this amazing truck is right next to my work is even better.  On a long Friday filled with reporting while hungover from going out the night before, this taco truck is my salvation.  

The first time my coworkers took me here they recommended the carne asada super taco, which was dead on.  I order it spicy with black beans.  It comes in a nice box and is huge with lettuce, guacamole, cheese, sour cream, beans, carne asada, tortillas, radish and lime.  This truck has never given me bad food and I usually hit it up once a week.

Don't be afraid that it's food from a truck - once you try it you'll understand.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Not sure why anyone would give this place less than 4 stars.  It's the real deal... just like the taco wagons in the Central Valley towns of Riverbank, Hughson, Patterson, etc.

I had the chicken burrito... VERY good.  I ordered it with black beans which were slightly undercooked; next time I'll go for the refried beans and I'm sure it will be excellent.

As for those of you that are a little wary about grabbing a burrito from a taco truck... Los Compadres proudly displays their perfect Food Safety score (100%) from the San Francisco Department of Public Health.
author: Marc H.

description: The tacologists at Los Compadres make a pretty good burrito for a reasonable price.  Also they can wrap like no other.
author: Paul K.

description:
most taco trucks i've been to always have delicious mexican food. this is the only decent place to get mexican food. the place in rincon sucks, burr-eat-o's sucks. there isn't really anything else in a half mile radius at least that can compete with this truck. 

I'm not saying this is the best mexican food EVAR, but in the area, there is no contest. You will not be disappointed if you eat here
author: John G.

description:
Delicious tacos!  The al pastor and pollo asado are amazing.

My coworker discovered this place on Monday, and he has been every day this week (it's now Wednesday) while I have joined him the past two.

Cheap, easy, and tasty.
author: Travis R.

description:
me: "hey liz, are there any good places around here to get a burrito?"
liz: "i think there's a taco truck down folsom but I'm not sure".

such a simple banter ended so magnificently it's just disgusting.  I only get 30 minutes for lunch, so the further I walked from 3rd street the more scared I became. 

Lo and behold a lone sign saying "taco truck" took me down an alley and there she was.  

10 people in line before me, I figured this place had something special so I chose to wait.  20 minutes later armed with my carne asada super burrito (exttra spicy of course) I rushed my ass back to work, making it back juuust in time for an at desk meal.

now at this point, my standards were raised.  I mean i could have gotten a pita wrap down stairs and not walked or eaten uncomfortably, but goddamn did this burrito make it worth while!!!

YUM.  the tortilla was grilled to perfection, and the ingredients were happily mushed together into a delightful burrito surprise exactly the way they should be.   The hotsauce wasn't really spicy at all... but I got chips/salsa on the side that made up for it.

I'll be back again, and next time I'll run faster!  i wonder if the tacos are just as good..
author: Joseph F.

description: These are the greatest al pastor tacos of all time. I think I ate 150 of them over the course of the 3 months I was in SF on my internship, working nearby....those tacos have yet to be challenged. (Get the spicy ones!)
author: Sanketh Y.

description: My go-to mexican place for tacos/burritos in the fidi. Forget the El Faro, baja fresh, and such. This is comparable to mission taquerias! I usually get the super tacos and a bag of chips and eat it as nachos but the super burritos fill me right up when i'm famished. best to get there when they open at 11 or you'll end up waiting a bit for your food.
author: Patrick M.

description:
So good!  Big ass chicken burrito (beans, cheese, rice, hot salsa and chicken) for $5!  Loves it.   Why is Pancho Villa charging me $8 for the same thing?

And there were cute guys in line, too!
author: Jackie D.

description:
Deliciousness.

It's a regular stop for lunch. At work, on almost a weekly basis, one of us will suggest the "taco truck run."

Yummy tacos (the carne asada and the el pastor are both so good...) It's worth the wait. $1.50 per taco. I always get around 3-4 depending on how hungry I am. Although one time I scarfed down 6 in one sitting, which I believe makes me the record holder in the office. 

We'll usually buy some and on a nice day, take it down by the water off the Embarcadero. Niiicceee.
author: lily l.

description:
This is the best option I've found thus far for a decent burrito in the Financial District.  There is usually a pretty long line, but on a nice day I don't mind.  I like the El Pastor Burrito with black beans.  They usually ask  you what kind of beans you want and if you want it spicy or not.  Their version of spicy has a pretty decent kick to it.  The wait is usually about 5-15 minutes depending on the line, but the burritos are pretty damn tasty and worth the walk over from Market/Beale.  

Its not to far from the water, so ordering a burrito and taking it down to the waterfront on a nice day is the bomb!
author: Ed B.

description: If you work in SOMA, you'll know that it's difficult to find good, affordable eats.  Which is exactly why I first tried The Taco Truck.  $5.50 for a burrito was a rare find.  The veggie burrito and the chicken burrito were okay.  The chicken was a bit heavy on the onions, but I am NOT an onion fan.  Now the Al Pastor (bbq pork) burrito...nothing less than a spicey, flavorful party in your mouth.  I always get the mild salsa, but even that has quite a kick.  The rice to meat to bean ratio is perfect and the quality of the burrito has been consistently satisfying.  Be sure to have some TUMS on hand (hey, eating spicey comes with a price) and if you come here any time after 12pm, expect to wait in line.
author: Joy H.

description:
2 chicken tacos
1 carne asada burrito with guac

Grand total: $9.  If you have a healthy appetite and less than 10 clams, this is the place.  

The chicken tacos were probably the best I've had in a long time.  The carne asada was pretty average (although authentic). There was a good sized line around the truck, but things moved along quickly and was well worth the ~10 minute wait.
author: Sunil A.

description:
In an area lacking good Mexican, this place is better than the rest and cheaper. I usually get the chicken burrito which for five bucks is an aiiight deal. Be careful though, the salsa espicy is spicy ~! 

A great place to grab a burrito on a sunny day and enjoy the views from the embarcadero.. seen!
author: john C.

description: For me, Los Compadres makes the perfect (regular) burrito -- fresh ingredients (cilantro and tomatoes burst), carnitas (crispy and tender in the right places), and it's the right size (I can easily over eat a whole forearm-sized burrito and always regret it). I hate over-stuffed, mushy, wet burritos, so no guac, salsa juice, or sour cream. Service has always been fast, organized, and accurate. At $5 (veggie) and $5.50 (carnitas), it's the right price, too. My only complaint is that I have to walk 4 blocks from work to get one.
author: D F.

description:
I was really excited to eat here. I read the reviews and was excited for greasy, basic, San Diego-esque taco truck food. I ordered the three soft tacos, one carne asada, one carnitas, and one pollo. All spicy. The guys were awesome and it was fast, but when I went to eat it, I honestly couldn't tell the difference between the three. At all. I'm wondering if maybe I got another person's order. 
To that effect, whatever meat I did eat was just alright, not a ton of flavor. I've definitely had better and cheaper taco truck food.
author: Brittany B.

description: I got the 3 tacos (I chose tongue!) for $4.50.  The tacos were loaded with onions, cilantro, and hot sauce, and the tongue meat was very tender with good fatty bits.  The picante sauce wasn't quite hot enough for my taste, but kept a nice warmth in my mouth for the next five blocks of walking after I'd scarfed down my tacos like some sort of disgusting crack fox.  As an extra bonus, I was very happy to see the cleanliness score of 100% they had been awarded last March.  Good street food, all around, even though they were out of carnitas and there was no head/brain meat.
author: Nick B.

description:
I love the spicy carne asada burrito w/ black beans and guacamole for only $5.50. It's big, cheap, and delicious. Get here early or prepare for a long wait as they prepare your food. Today I waited 20 minutes because there were about 15 people ahead of me. Crazy, but oh so worth it!

Bonus point--they serve Coke in glass bottles!
author: Alice N.

description: Absolutely love this place and I'm one of those transplanted Texans that always complains about Cal-Mex.  This place rocks!  Expect lines, but they move through it pretty quickly.
author: Rene H.

description:
*tear*  

good, authentic & CHEAP mexican food.  HOT hot sauce.  nice guys in a truck cookin'.

makes this native San Diegan feel like i'm just steps from the border again.

it's like "home" :)
author: Carol O.

description: On a sunny day, there's almost nothing better than grabbing a budget-friendly carnitas super taco (fully loaded with rice & beans, lettuce, cheese, avocado, sour cream, fresh salsa and a perfectly tongue-tingling hot sauce) for an outdoor lunch along the Embarcadero.  The pork is perfectly salted, and chewy/crisp -- in other words, perfect.  Don't plan on being productive after finishing a meal at Los Compadres, though -- you'll be blissed out in a food coma.
author: Michelle T.

description:
it's decent. i ordered a super burrito w/ carnitas. i asked for "mild" sauce. oh boy, i'd hate to try their "hot" sauce ... my mouth / face was on fire ... sweat pouring down my face. the carnitas wasn't as good as i would have liked - it was a little tough. i'll have to give this place a few more tries (perhaps order the chicken next time, which is supposed to be good) before i base an overall honest opinion about this place.

UPDATE: so i went back today and ordered the grilled chicken super burrito - thinking it'd be better. not the case. the chicken tasted old and there were a lot of pieces with gristle in it. this place is getting rave reviews, but i want to like it and i've given it two chances thus far, but i think i'm done with this place. i originally rated it 3 stars, but i removed one - based on today's experience. maybe the tacos are better?
author: James J.

description:
Unreal.

I was born and raised in LA (yeah yeah, get over it and keep reading) , and while I can honestly say that I find SF to be superior to that sprawling megalopolis in just about every way...Mexican food ain't one of 'em. Yet, for the near decade I've lived in this city, I've had to suffer through Bay Area denizens praising such-and-such taqueria for their "great chips" and "awesome burritos." But you know what? You don't get Mexican food for chips and rolled tortillas. Don't get me wrong, those things are good..but there's a lot more to it than that. The pinto beans (you want black beans, go to Cuba, honey) melding ever-so-perfectly with seasoned meat of your choice and a mixture of sour cream and guacamole that is a concoction in and of itself...cheese that's not froufrou and overpowering, but puts just the right finishing touch on a pico de gallo with a kick low enough to allow you to keep eating without putting your fork down. This is Mexican food. And where did I FINALLY find this in SF? My beloved Los Compadres Taco Truck.

That's right. Tucked elusively on a corner across the street from the Gap building, with maybe 4 metal tables and chairs on a pigeon-visited sidewalk, my Mexican haven sits and beckons passerbys with smells reminiscent of East LA's El Tepeyac (a.k.a. Manuel's). That's a good thing, btw. And like any good taco wagon, it's dirt cheap. I'm pretty sure you pay dollar for pound at this place, which means my Super Taco (don't let the name fool you - you can't imagine what this really is) is 5 pounds. When I add my Specialty's cookie from up the street to that order, sure, I'm too weighed down to get up from my desk for an hour. But after that hour passes and I've washed it all down,  I'm ready to do it again - no regrets!
author: Kiesha R.

description: Everyone else has said it, but it bears repeating....  Not as cheap or as tasty as you'd get in the Mission, but one of your best bets for Mex food in CubicleLand.
author: Andi T.

description: Certainly not the best truck in the Bay, but the food is very decent and damned if the super taco isn't enough food for both lunch and dinner... for $5.
author: Catherine H.

description: Los Compadres (or El Tonyaense if you're at Best Buy) is just ok. It's not the cheapest, fastest or most delicious of taco trucks, but it's nice just having one there. The best part about these guys is that they rent out their services (mobile catering anyone?) for parties. If you decide to brave the truck, here are a few things to keep in mind: 1. DO speak up; the order window was made for guys 6ft tall and up, 2.) DON'T pay any attention to the section of the menu with the regular tacos, they're teeny and more like potstickers made with tortillas before they get rolled up, 3.) DO try the super tacos, mmm, they're the star of this show for sure. Somehow they're closer to nachos than tacos, but delicious nonetheless, and way better than the burritos, which are just so-so.
author: Mandy Z.

description:
Twice, I tried the super veggie burrito ($5) and it was terrible. The rice was burnt. The beans were dry. Way too much sour cream. No salsa to speak of. Not spicy. No chips. One napkin.

It's nice to have mexican food close to your work, but I think any Mission tacqueria that was reheated would beat the soggy mess of this taco truck.

As I was picking up my order I asked for salsa and the guy said it was already in the burrito. I asked for extra and he said it was 50 cents. Give me a break: you're charging for a thimble of salsa??!!?
author: Mac G.

description: Had a al pastor burrito from here.  Nonplussed.  Meat was overcooked, oily (not the good kind either), mushy and not very tasty.  I seriously doubt I'll be back.
author: Mary P.

description: 3 tacos for $4.50, one pollo, asada, & carnitas...can't beat that.
author: Pickle R.

description: I used to work in the Gap buildings on this street, and so I've had my share of their chicken burrito many times. I always told myself that I'd just eat half of the burrito, but it was always too good to leave any leftovers. What I like about their burrito is the meat, which is infused with great flavor. The cilantro makes it even better! I agree that it's better to go earlier than later because there's always a line of people.
author: Michele O.

description: Not to sound like hater or anything but i got violent food poisoning from eating here. If you read my pass reviews you can tell i heart Mexican food. i ordered 3 tacos carne asada and carnitas quesadilla for lunch. That evening around 5 pm something didn't feel right. Next day PTO day due to violent yakking and dookie booty. aiyaaa no good for me.
author: maria t.

description: I usually get tacos here, which I feel deserve 4 stars.  But the burritos are MEHHH!  2 stars.  They're ok but I've had better.  Maybe it's the seasoning of the rice & beans.. don't know what it is but I would rather get the burritos at Rincon Center instead, which taste better and are cheaper...  Unfortunately I have to bring down my rating to 3 stars.  Regardless I will continue to be a dedicated customer... but I'm going to stick to the tacos from now on!
author: Justine L.

description: They don't call it the super taco for nothing, the burritos are asi asi, but i'm so down with my friend supertaco, and i love spicy mexican food and if you tell them to spice it up they will
author: Chrammy D.

description: This truck won't be replacing my regular lunch routine spots, nor will it be replacing my burrito vendor but in a pinch and considering it's the only one in the area,it fills a need. The pastor was tasty, but a little light for a "super" and I got the majority of the cheese in the south end of my north-travelling 'ritto.
author: Nate B.

description: I was shocked that I could get a burrito this delicious from a taco truck. You will not be disappointed if you go for the carnitas super burrito. Yum yum yum!
author: Erin C.

description: Oh, those little tacos, I love them good.  Perfect little tacos (not the super tacos) with radish and jalapeno on the side. Well worth the walk and the wait!
author: Ashton E.

description: amaze. great service. awesome fried pork and bbq pork tacos.  quesadilla with chicken was shockingly good too, v fresh and chicken-y.  $6 for 3 small soft tacos.  so delicious.  would go again if i lived in the area. and by again i mean several times a week.
author: mary l.

description: The carne asada quesadilla is FANTASTIC. I often get two quesadillas (the other one al pastor) and a bottle of coke. I'll eat half and half of each and save the other halves for an afternoon snack or dinner.
author: David P.

description: This taco truck is good for 1 menu item - Tacos! Go figure! The burritos aren't all that. But their tacos are perfect. The sauce definitely has a kick, so be cautious. But I love spicy food, so I loved it.  I always get 3 tacos with carnitas - $4.50. Never been disappointed!
author: Samir P.

description:
update 5/29 -- just had the super taco and wow!!!!  4 bucks and a good hearty meal.  not too unhealthy either especially if you dump the sour cream and get the black beans!  can wait to go back!

---

a good burrito for the price!  the key here is to order no rice and you in turn get lots more meat.  i had the carne asada super burrito and while being tasty, it had way too much cilantro, not enough cheese and not enough guac.  the burrito was a definite gut bomb that effectively stopped me from being productive at work afterwards.  next time i'll try out the tacos, which i hear is quite good.
author: Swarup B.

description: I loved my chicken burrito.  Loved it so much that I ate the whole thing.  Yes, that's right - the whole thing.  Packed full of spicy salsa, cilantro, and the perfect balance of rice/cheese/guac to chicken, I am ridiculously full and equally happy.  Next time, I swear I'll cut it in half immediately and save the rest for the next day.  Really, I will...
author: Julie L.

description: came here to get some tacos cause it's close to work. i'm not a big fan of soft tacos but hard shells arent exactly REALLL MEXICAN either, but still i prefer hard shells. anyways for $5, you get 3 soft tacos, some beets, carrots, and a big pepper which was pretty good. It wasn't that filling for me (maybe cause I havent eaten all day), but it was pretty good and spicy. It was a little too spicy but then again, i didn't pick which spice I wanted. Overall, it was affordable in the area and it was decent. I will come here again and try the burritos or quesadillas!!
author: Marsha C.

description: So many had bad stuff to say about "the Taco Truck".  I have not had a bad experience at this mobile establishment.  All pretty delicious and delightfully spicy.  I was a little disappointed in the price increases, but still cheaper then eating at a lot of the other places downtown.  I gave it 3 stars for being a tasty taco truck.  I've had better, but it hits the spot.  Pull up Folsom St & Spear St on Google maps Street View and you will see the taco truck in action.
author: Shea B.

description: decent food. i made the mistake of ordering 2 super tacos one day- whooa nelly 2 much food!!!!!!!!! Great taco though. Pretty big portions.
author: Dizzy B.

description: Get the chicken if it hasn't run out. There's something about this place. Service isn't always the fastest, but the taste keeps me coming.
author: Wil M.

description: For lunch the other day I decided to get out of the office and treat myself to the taco truck.. I've heard so much about it from my co-workers so I went over there and stood in the LONG line. I was there about 1:00 on a Friday so who knows if the line is longer or shorter at 12:00 noon but it is a bit of a wait. I ordered a Chicken Taco with the works- I think it is the Grande? It comes in a box with 2 flour tortillas at the bottom and the "filling" on top. Technically this is an open-faced taco.. aka Tostada. I just want you to know what to expect when you open the box as it doesn't look like a taco. This was the perfect amount of food for me; I think the burrito would have given me a serious food coma. I will definitely go back  when I visit our SF office on Spear.
author: Jen S.

description: Stellar al pastor and pollo asado tacos. Probably the best I've had in the Bay Area. Normally I don't get carne asada or pollo asado since they tend to be flavorless and dry, but the meats here were tender and juicy. Next time I'll try the carnitas and lengua.
author: Brooks S.

description: I got a regular carne asada burrito for $6, and it was just ok. Not as big as burritos in the Mission at comparable prices, and the meat had too many tendons (or whatever those hard-to-chew bits are), making it awkward to eat in front of coworkers.
author: M H.

description:
i've been to the taco truck in the civic center hood, and both times have been pleased with my orders.

the supertacos are heaping with lettuce, cheese, radishes (yay), and come with a side of hot pickled peppers (yay again). awesome.  you'll find the meat and beans buried at the bottom. squirt some lime on the whole thing, stir it all up, and go to town. 

my friend had the super burrito and that was really tasty as well!
in fact, i dare say it was one of the better burritos i've had in a long, long time.
author: jennifer y.

description: I don't know WHAT took me so long to review Los Compadres, but they have the best deal and yummy food. They pack my all meat burrito with carnitas that I get like a pig in a tub full o'mud - HAPPY! Oh and their three taco deal for $4.50 is a steal. After I've cleared my head w/a walk along the Embarcadero I usually reward myself with a trip to the truck. Ahhh life's simple pleasures...
author: C P.

description:
I so badly wanted to love this place. I work two blocks away and am a burritoholic. Nuff said. But now that I finally had the chance to try it out after my office moved the neighborhood a few months back, I'm disappointed, and the chances that I will become a regular are slim. 

In fairness, there was a lot to like about the carne asada burrito I ordered. Good balance between meat and beans and rice and other ingredients. (You gotta hate a bad beans-to-rice-to-meat ratio.) Salsa flavorful. But overall, the thing was just too damn greasy. A little bit is understandable, especially from a taco truck. But this was out-of-bounds oily. Oh yeah, and when I want salsa picante, I want it picante. So-hot-you're-wiping-sweat-from-your-brow hot. This didn't come close.

I'll give this place another chance to redeem itself and will revisit my review if it does. But for now, sorry Compadres, I'm taking my bad burrito-eating self elsewhere.
author: Tom G.

description: Just had a carne asada taco there. Delicious! Service was great, price is outstanding, I will definitely be coming back soon, like, in an hour. =)
author: Nicole C.

description: This truck ranks in my top three favorite restaurants in the city, I'm still trying to think of the other two. I used to work down there, so it was perfect, the little seating area is brilliant, with the canopy protecting you from the sun, giving you a 5 star, fine dining feel, you know? My only gripe is that there's no beer, and how perfect would that be? C'mon fellas, just keep an iced cold tub full, no one will say anything. They'll be thrown into the sea. Have I been to heaven? Well, try the carnitas quesadilla, with a little extra cilantro, and spicy, and you'll know what I mean. EAT THERE!!!!
author: Maui G.

description: I wish they sold Mexican coke, but they do have a great burrito for 5 bucks.  I like the little seats right along side the truck.  It's a good spot to sit away from my tiny little cube and people watch for an hour at lunch.
author: Jessica T.

description: This burrito truck is fantastic and the price is right.  It is about a block away from my office and I make it a point to go at least once a week.  I also make it my responsibility to introduce any new hires to the burrito truck when they join us.
author: Greg M.

description: Hey, picked up lunch a few days ago ... and good food for a truck.  Not bad!
author: John B.

description: love this truck! i am a sucker for street tacos and the ones coming from this truck make it seem unreal. how can such a delicious fete come from such a mobile home? the tortillas are some of the best and do their due diligence in holding the yummy within. the carne asada is tender and juicy. and, i am in love with cilantro and lime...so, the more the better. the side of pickled veggies are just a bonus. taco truck...i am sold, where do i sign?
author: Marjie T.

description:
since i work across the street, i frequent this place A LOT because it's consistently good and consistently cheap. 

carne asada super taco :)


can't go wrong with this place.
author: Matt K.

description:
Pros:
Good flavor. 
Meat is seasoned well and juicy
Hot sauce is spicy
Fresh ingredients
Price

Cons:
No $1 taco truck tacos!
Charged me for a super burrito and gave me a regular burrito!

Come back? 
Yes. I will give them a second chance to give me what I ordered
author: David L.

description: I am new to the city and a co-worker introduced me to this taco truck.  It is fair to say I was skeptical at first, i mean common, street meat?  However this place is extremely clean and the food is delicious, I am by no means a expert of mexican cuisine however this is the best burrito I have to date in San Fran.  The pork is so tasty I want to eat it until I lose consciousness.  Need I say more?
author: Nolan E.

description: i heart the taco truck!!  first of all, it cracks me up that its a truck that randomly parks near my office and has yummy mexican food.  but once you get around the part that your food is cooked in a truck, its all good!  my faves include the tacos and the quesadilla, but i havent tried the burritos yet (although they look bigger than my head!).  i am all about the spicy chicken - its great.  some people have said that it can be a little dodgy, but my experiences have been okay so i stick by my 4 stars!  caliente!
author: Carolyn B.

description: OK, I finally tried this place again and it is pretty good.  Not as good as most joints in the Mission but hey this is a taco truck after all.
author: Joseph S.

description: pretty good burritos for downtown, definitely kicks bur-eat-tos ass on both flavor and price, ouch bet that boins! proud mary keep on boining... Also just a note to that person flipping out about an eyelash in their burrito, did it ever occur to you that it was probably your eyelash?
author: Ian H.

description: I heard great things about this taco truck from several of my friends. Shared the taco plate and the burrito. Tacos had the typical cilantro, onion, and hot sauce with a radish coin. Hot sauce was really spicy, but I enjoyed it. The carne asada and fried pork were good but the lengua I didn't like too much. It had a weird taste to it. I know, it's beef tongue but, still weird. I've had them at other places and the beef tongue flavor is usually well masked so you don't taste the "tongue". I'd probably just stick with the carne asada and fried pork next time. The burrito was good. Great deal. I'd go back.
author: J C.

description: thanks to all the yelpers my bf found this taco truck ....i love taco trucks!  we got here during lunch rush hour so the line was pretty long but worth the wait.  we ordered 3 tacos and a super burrito...let me just say carne asada is the way to go.  i havent found a taco truck that ive loved in a while.  now i have two favs....one in the city and another in the east side of san jose.  i cant wait to go back.
author: Sheryll D.

description: Went there today to order a carne asada regular burrito for $5.50.  sign said meat, beans, rice, hot sauce, and cilantro.  apparently, they forgot the cilantro.  also, meat was on the dry side and a bit salty.  size WAS NOT huge.  just okay.  cheese, pico de gallo, guac cost extra.  so based on this visit, i give it 2 stars only (per yep, that means, "Meh. I've experienced better").  honestly, i think i prefer chipotle because i can get lettuce, cheese, and pico de gallo added for no extra costs along with a bigger size burrito for $6.85.  without any special reason, i don't plan to go back.
author: Andrew C.

description: When I hear taco truck, I say "where?"  I'm all for it.  So I had to venture out to try this one out, esp since Mexican food around my work is sub par.  The truck is very clean and they have some seating-- quite an upgrade I think.  I order a steak burrito and I am thinking that I really like it.  Except I spend the entire time thinking, is this beef or is this pork?  Beef or pork??  The meat was that mysterious.  I still dont know what it was.  It tasted good, was a little greasy (but I would expect that), I just have to know what I am eating, so that's why I gave it 2 stars.
author: Erica S.

description: Awsome super taco! I was skeptical, but after seeing the crowd standing on the street corner, I figured there must be something to this and gave it a try. I live in the Mission and this is definitely on par with what I'm used to. However, $5 for a super taco is more than you would pay in the Mission, but a good deal for downtown. BTW, this is way better than the taco joint in Rincon Center.
author: V M.

description: had the carne asada burrito and it was just ok. the meat was a little over-cooked, as was the rice. if i worked close by, i'd probably still go here on a regular basis because i love burritos, but since i'm closer to taqueria mana, which i think is much better, i'll just stick with that.
author: AJ C.
